Headline: Barron's(2/19) 13D Filings: Investors Report To The SEC
Story: (From BARRON'S)   13Ds are supposed to be filed within 10 days of an entity's attaining 5% or more of any class of a company's securities. Subsequent changes must be reported on amended filings. This material is from filings released by the SEC from  Feb. 8 through 14.   Source: Corporate Filings Alert     Activists     Mair Holdings (MAIR)   Riley Investment Management and Mair reached agreement on board expansion and director appointments. Mair will enlarge its board fromseven members to eight and named John Ahn, a Riley principal, as a director and nominating committee member. Riley has opposed Mair's bid to sell its Mesaba Airlines unit to Northwest Airlines (ticker: NWACQ). Riley has 923,152 shares (4.5% of the total outstanding).     Yardville National Bancorp(YANB)   An investor group including Seidman & Associates said a court had found that the bank holding company's directors had breached their fiduciary duty. The Seidman affiliates had sued the New Jersey company to enjoin it from implementing a "new qualification bylaw" and to halt any attempt to prevent Lawrence B. Seidman or a Seidman-backed candidate from running for the board. As of Feb. 8, the group had 933,435 shares (8.75%).     Lear (LEA)   Pzena Investment Management said that it may talk with Lear's independent directors about its opposition to the proposed buyout offer for the auto-parts maker by an affiliate of billionaire investor Carl Icahn. "We would like to remind the board of its fiduciary  obligation . . . and urge you to seek other offers," Pzena said. The firm added that it would like to meet with the independent directors to discuss the company's valuation. Pzena holds 6,776,279 shares (10.05%).     Tier Technologies (TIER.PK)   Giant Investment said that it will nominate a director to Tier's board and that it wants to help the transaction processor evaluate strategic alternatives. Giant said Tier lacks the scale to remain independent and should explore a merger or sale. Giant and its affiliates want to sign a confidentiality agreement with Tier to evaluate these alternatives. Giant holds 1,834,000 shares (9%).     Original Filings     Lenox Group (LNX)   Clinton Group said it had acquired Lenox shares because they were "undervalued and represented an attractive investment opportunity." It said it may hold discussions with the tableware maker's executives, board or with other shareholders about the company's plans. Clinton owns 958,380 shares (6.8%).     Increases in Holdings     Reuters Group (RTRSY)   ValueAct Capital Management lifted its position to 66,301,212 shares (5.2%) by buying 7,057,763 from Dec. 12, 2006, to Feb. 8, at $8.52 to $8.90 a share.     Decreases in Holdings     SJW (SJW)   Funds run by Mario Gabelli's Gamco Investors own 1,006,300 shares (5.5%), after selling 144,100 from Dec. 16, 2006, to Feb. 1, at $34.64 to $41.44 each.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Timken Remake Still In Act I
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jim McTague   When investors grabbed shares of bearing maker Timken early last week, they nudged toward the $30 mark -- surprising, since a week earlier, the company had reported disappointing earnings. Otherwise, the shares have been rangebound for months.   Some bulls see the shares (ticker: TKR) breaking above 30 this year, citing Timken's plans to play down its low-margin, high-volume auto business and ramp up specialized aerospace-product sales.   It's a compelling story,and likely to have a happy ending. Yet like Wagner's excruciatingly long Ring Cycle, this opera will hit many highs and lows before the final act. Meanwhile, the bulls appear to have placed their bets too early: The 2007 outlook suggests a price lower than 28.   Timken, which boasts that it "keeps the world turning," is the world's largest manufacturer of tapered roller bearings -- devices used to reduce friction between parts in engines and other machines. It operates in 27 countries and has annual sales of about $5 billion and a stock-market value around $2.8 billion. The Canton, Ohio, firm also owns two steel mills that make seamless tubing.   Timken products are found in nearly every U.S.-made vehicle. This once was an unalloyed source of pride and profits. However, when the Motor City hits the brakes -- as it's doing now -- Timken gets a nasty whiplash. And the problem will only worsen if the Detroit three don't regain market share. Hence, Timken is reinventing itself as a specialty producer for aerospace, energy and rail equipment.   On Feb. 7, Timken reported fourth-quarter earnings of $35.3 million, or 37 cents a share, 63% below the year-earlier figure. For all of 2006, Timken netted $222.5 million, or $2.36, on $4.97 billion in sales. In 2005, it made $260.3 million, or $2.81 a share, on $4.82 billion.   For '07, the company expects earnings from continuing operations to rebound to $2.50-$2.70; analysts originally had been projecting $2.77. Disappointing demand from Detroit cost Timken nine cents a share in the fourth quarter, and an increase in auto-warranty reserves for some defective bearings from one of its plants cost another eight cents.   Analyst Mark Parr of KeyBanc Capital Markets has a 52-week target of 35. "The company's sensitivity to autos in conjunction with all of its manufacturing-restructuring activities over the past couple of years clearly has hurt earnings momentum," says Parr. "But given the recent run-up in auto-supplier stocks, Timken looks very timely right now."   He adds that Timken's EPS guidance for 2007 isn't that far out of line with the consensus prediction. "Our own 2007 forecast was $2.70," he says. His 35 target is six times enterprise value to Ebitda -- or earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, a measure of cash flow -- within a normalized range of five to eight times. Enterprise value is stock-market value, plus debt, minus cash.   (Timken, it should be noted, is a large KeyBanc client. The firm advised Timken on the sale of Latrobe Steel last year, a deal that roiled the stock because many shareholders believed the mill was worth much more than the $215 million Timken received. Timken also has a $375 million loan and $500 million line of credit with Keybanc.)   Robert Schenosky, a managing partner at Jefferies & Co., is guarded in his assessment of Timken. While he applauds management's restructuring efforts, he says the auto business remains a cause for concern. In his view, the bullish case for Timken rests on the assumption that the overall economy will markedly improve. "We don't share that enthusiasm," he says. He views the consensus estimates for Timken for both '07 and '08 as unrealistically high. "It's difficult for a stock's price to fight through when the majority of estimates proved to be too aggressive," says Schenosky. He rates Timken a Hold, warning that "We would not put a Buy on it at 28 and some change." Timken's 52-week low is 27.46.   Wachovia senior analyst Wendy Caplan estimates 2007 EPS at $2.40 and '08 at $2.50, since she foresees weaker steel profits and a slower-than-expected auto recovery. She assumes 11 times earnings, which translates into a stock price in the high 20s.   Keeley Asset Management of Chicago owned 1.78 million Timken shares, as of Sept. 30. Robert Becker, a senior vice president, is disappointed that Timken's stock has been flat to down since then. He'd like Timken to become more like Kaydon (KDN), a company with "screaming margins" on specialty products like bearings for windmills and medical equipment: "Kaydon sells in twos and threes and Timken sells in the thousands." But Kaydon makes a lot more on each item. Kaydon CEO Brian Campbell tells Barron's that his bearings are so specialized, he's not worried about foreign competition.   Although Becker expects Timken to get there, he says it will be a two-steps-forward, one-step-backward struggle. "We hope there's a pickup. We think it is reasonably valued and that its balance sheet has improved, and that management is capable of improving its operations," he comments. "If we didn't think it would do well, we would not be in the stock; we are patient," Becker says.   Investors should probably be patient, too: It could be at least a year before the Fat Lady sings.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:04 ET (05:04 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Plugged In: At Last: The Video Revolution
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   The video revolution is here. after years of talk and promise, digital television is finally beginning to see the light of day. At this year's Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas -- where more television screens were concentrated in one spot than anywhere else on earth -- the hot topic was mobile video's emergence. There are finally wireless networks, especially in places like Korea, that boast enough bandwidth to deliver quality images. Handset makers, led by Samsung and Apple (ticker: AAPL), are trying to make devices to handle whatever Hollywood and the music industry pump out.   But mobile video is just an extension of a much larger phenomenon: online television. Some folks view online TV as Internet-Protocol television, or IPTV, which sort of narrowly defines the world in which digital images are distributed using Internet technology. Telephone carriers are investing heavily in IPTV as one way to deliver television service over their wireline networks in competition with their rivals in the cable industry, which have been snaring legacy telephone customers, left and right.   Yet looking at it another way, which is what Merriman Curhan Ford's research director, Tim Savageaux, has done, online television can be viewed as a broad investment theme that encompasses an entire ecosystem of content, mobile, Web and communications concerns that should benefit from the online-television trend. Social networks and the You Tube craze are just the tips of the iceberg when it comes to dramatic shifts of advertising dollars away from traditional broadcasters to new media outfits, says Savageaux, who believes "that video-based advertising could become the fastest-growing segment in online advertising over the next five years."   Certainly, big media portals such as Google (GOOG) and Yahoo! (YHOO) will benefit from the trend, but so should online car sites, such as Autobytel (ABTL) and the gay Website PlanetOut (LGBT), which runs syndicated TV shows over the Internet. What's more, digital-marketing companies and online ad agencies, such as Seattle's aQuantive (AQNT) also stand to do well as traditional broadcasting begins to give way to the digital age, the analyst says.   To be sure, many telecoms are also licking their chops at the latest video trends. Cisco (CSCO) CEO John Chambers didn't buy cable set-top box-maker Scientific-Atlanta for nothing, justifying the acquisition by explaining that video networking would be integral to most communications networks.     At MCF's summit on online video in San Francisco last week, Harmonic (HLIT) CEO Patrick Harshman noted that his company is optimistic that spending by traditional customers in the satellite and cable TV industries will be robust. But he was even more buoyed by the newest entrants -- telephone carriers -- "and their competitive compulsion to get into the video business."   Harmonic is a leading maker of digital video and fiberoptic systems with video-on-demand and high-def technologies. MCF's Savageaux upgraded Harmonic to a Buy last July based on the promise of higher orders and improved gross margins. His target: 13. Late last week, the stock was around 9.   After a strong fourth quarter, the analyst bumped up his 2007 forecast on the promise of better-than-expected orders from cable and satellite outfits. Any upside from the telcos, at this point, would be mostly gravy. Pour it on.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Driven By A Vision Of Global Growth
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Sandra Ward   Interview With David Herro   Chief Investment Officer, International Equities, Harris Associates     In his 15-year tenure at Chicago-based Harris Associates and its Oakmark family of funds, where he oversees $22.5 billion invested in international stocks, David Herro has delivered superior returns with dazzling consistency. He does it by making big bets on a relatively small number of stocks trading below their intrinsic value. Generating strong free cash flow iskey, and the companies he homes in on have managements that allocate capital intelligently. Herro steeredthe Oakmark International Fund to a nearly 31% gain last year. Since its launch in September 1992, it has returned 13.7% a year, on average; in the past five years, it has advanced 18%, again on average. Herro is also the portfolio manager of Oakmark International Small Cap, which has  averaged a  15.75% return since it started in November 1995 -- and soared nearly 35% in 2006, winning Herro the title of Morningstar International Fund Manager of the Year.     Barron's: You had another good year last year, without investing in China or other emerging markets.   Herro: There have been times in our history where we've had very high weightings in emerging markets like Brazil and Latin America and Asia. But we are stingy value people, and we think a lot of the good news is priced into the emerging-markets stocks and none of the bad. That's not necessarily a comment on the macro economy but on corporate governance, transparency, profit margins, and profitability. These are all issues that have to be considered when valuing businesses and in euphoric periods the market tends to ignore them.   Think about it: We are about to celebrate the 10-year anniversary of the start of the Asian crisis. When prices got slammed, we started buying, and we were about six months early. It ended up being just fine, and the period from 1998 to 2002 defined us and got people interested in investing with us.     Q: What trends do you see on the international investing scene?   A: The old and busted growth-blue-chips, whether they are in the U.S. or based internationally, are the most attractively priced equity assets out there. This is where there is value. For example, GlaxoSmithKline [ticker: GSK] stock is trading at the same level it was in the mid '90s, and yet its earnings power is substantially higher. There has been a massive de-rating that has happened in such industries as pharmaceuticals, media, and consumer nondurables.     Q: A de-rating?   A: Earnings have kept going up, but share prices have either stagnated or stayed the same. Stocks that used to trade at, say, 15 times cash flow and 20 times earnings are not trading anywhere near those levels. That's partly due to the strength in small-caps. Consider that the Oakmark International Fund and the Oakmark International Small Cap have handily outperformed over the past five years. They are managed by the same people and have the same research team. Everything is the same, except the hunting ground is different.   The five-year performance of Oakmark International Small Cap fund is 26% per year over the last five years. The five year number of the Oakmark International Fund is 18%, which is an 800-basis-point [eight-percentage-point] difference per year over five years. That reflects a major revaluation of small companies and the fact that lots of money has flooded into them. Money has also flooded into real estate, metals, mining, cyclicals, natural resources, and emerging markets. Money has gone into hot sectors and less economically safe sectors. There has been a massive move out of blue chips.     Q: What does this mean looking forward for your small-cap fund?   A: The caveat is, and I've been saying this for a year: Looking out five years, I expect our core international strategy will outperform our core international small-cap strategy just based on the valuations of businesses. Small-caps are trading roughly 15% to 20% more than their brethren in large-cap land and in many instances it is not deserved. It is getting harder and harder for us to find small stocks to replace those that we sell because they've hit their targets. That's a caution, and people don't want to hear it. On my conference calls with advisers they say, oh, you are just being conservative. Maybe it is conservative, but I'm trying to be honest.     Q: Have you been raising cash in the small-cap fund?   A: Yes, it is probably 6% or 7%, up from the more traditional 3% or 4%. It is not cash-heavy by any means, but it is more cash than we normally have. Small-caps are not categorically overpriced. They are not speculatively overpriced. It is just difficult to find good value, especially with the private-equity types gnawing at them.     Q: Should they continue to benefit from private-equity buyouts and merger activity?   A: We saw a great deal of activity last year in both strategies, because there is so much money floating around. I don't know how long it is going to last, probably for another year or two. Eventually, the people who are seeding these alternative-investment strategies might realize the risk-return payoff may not be what it used to be. But that is going to take some time to develop.     Q: Where are you seeing value among the large blue chips? I see a lot of car companies in your portfolio.   A: There are three car companies and we own each for different reasons. Our top position is DaimlerChrysler [DCX] -- don't laugh. We started buying it maybe halfway through last year and now it has become a 4% position.     Q: Don't tell me you liked the ads?   A: No, they were terrible. But the market was completely missing the turnaround at Mercedes-Benz Autos as well as the commercial vehicles. Investors have been solely focused on Chrysler. Chrysler is certainly having its issues, but one could argue that Chrysler is in a slightly a better position than Ford and GM. Yet, a healthy Chrysler is less than 20% of Daimler's value. This is a big company and it has a lot of different aspects to it and shareholders of the world have been ignoring that Mercedes' operating margin has gone from 1% or 2% to 7%. A similar expansion has taken place in profitability on the commercial-vehicle side. There are some real changes taking place at Mercedes in design and, more importantly, quality. You can see it in the sales numbers.   There is a new S-class that came out, and that is a very important product for Mercedes because they sell a decent amount of them and they are high-margin. They have a new C-class coming out in about two months. The only new product that doesn't seem to be doing well is the R-class, which is a cross between an SUV and a minivan. Chief Executive Dieter Zetsche has done a good job getting this company focused on its business.     Q: How do you feel about a possible sale of Chrysler?   A: If they try and exact enough value as possible, we're all for it. We do not have an overly optimistic valuation of Chrysler in our models. At this stage, it's probably not the best time to sell. When they iron things out with the United Auto Workers and start generating cash flow, they'll get a better price.     Q: What about BMW?   A: BMW [BMW.Germany] is a different story than Daimler. The good news is that demographics and the rising wealth in the world work out very well for both of these companies. These are the only two global luxury-automobile brands. Audi really isn't global. Lexus isn't global. BMW is a great company. It gets double-digit returns on capital. It seems to increase units about 6% a year, which is a very good number. It has a strong balance sheet, is very well run and is underpriced. On financials, they seem rock solid. They have net cash on the balance sheet and they've actually bought back stock, which is very un-Germanlike.     Q: Then there's Honda.   A: Honda [HMC] is kind of a BMW for the mass market. It is almost an American company, in the way they think about returns.     Q: How undervalued are these companies in your view?   A: Daimler is around 50% undervalued. BMW is about 45% undervalued and Honda is about 20% undervalued. Honda has had a nice run, so it is not as cheap as it used to be and it is not as big of a position as it used to be for us.     Q: You can't be thinking we are going to have some kind of global slowdown if these are your picks.   A: We don't believe in a global slowdown. From a macroeconomic perspective, I'm fairly much of a global bull. I don't know about the short-term future. But longer-term, I'm very bullish on global economic growth. The theme I've been preaching about for 10 years is finally happening: When you have three-fifths of the world's population finally becoming consumers, that is going to have an impact. The second biggest market for the BMW 7 Series outside the U.S. is China. If China or any of the emerging markets could add 100 to 150 basis points of growth to the top line of, say, a Diageo, a Nestle, a BMW, that is significant to its valuation in the long haul and that's exactly what's happening.   We've added HSBC [HBC] Hong Kong Shanghai Bank, which looks like a stock that hasn't done much. Its local shares are trading at 919 pence. But this is a company that has good exposure to Asia and to the emerging world. They have a huge franchise in the greater Hong Kong and Southern China area. North America, including Latin America, is almost one-third of their business. One-third is Europe and one-third is Asia.     Q: But HSBC is now paying the price for expanding into the U.S. mortgage and subprime lending business.   A: HSBC bought Household International in 2003 and now people are worried about the subprime lenders. This is the opportunity. That is probably 15% of their business. This is a company that is generally very well-managed, very good at controlling risk, trades at 11 1/2 times this year's consensus earnings estimates, and yields 4 1/2%. This is a very good global franchise with great exposure to the growth areas of the world trading at two times book.     (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: German Transport Min Proposes Tax Breaks For 'Green' Cars
Story: BERLIN (AP)--Germans who buy environmentally friendly automobiles should be rewarded with tax breaks, the country's transport minister said in a newspaper editorial published Saturday.   Writing in the Sueddeutsche Zeitung newspaper, Wolfgang Tiefensee proposed tax breaks for people who purchase automobiles that emit less carbon dioxide, burn less fuel and are overall more energy efficient.   "The more environmentally friendly the car, the bigger the tax break should be," Tiefensee wrote. "Whoever protects the environment saves money."   Already a tax is in the works that envisions charging more to drivers of vehicles with higher carbon dioxide emissions. But Tiefensee's proposal foresees measuring the overall environmental friendliness of a vehicle, including energy efficient motors and lower fuel consumption.   "The automobile industry has to do more to protect the environment," said Tiefensee, a member of the Social Democratic Party.   Germany's powerful automobile industry, which includes giants such as Volkswagen AG (VLKAY) DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX) and BMW AG (BMW.XE), has been reluctant to adopt more environmentally friendly options and recently forced the European Union to water down a proposed law requiring emissions reductions by 2012.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 11:25 ET (16:25 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Power Of Gazprom Comes Under Fire In Moscow Cabinet - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--A Cabinet split emerged in Russia's government Friday over the growing power of the state-owned energy giant Gazprom (SIBN.RS), the Times reported Saturday.   The paper reports that German Gref, the Economic Development Minister, issued a startling warning that Gazprom's all-out expansion strategy threatened to extinguish prospects for the growth of a market economy in Russia.   The paper says Gref told a conference in Krasnoyarsk, Siberia, that Gazprom's rise represented a return to the "monopolistic capitalism of the 19th Century."   Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 07:01 ET (12:01 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) European Trader: L'Oreal's "Masstigious" Potential
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Matthew Curtin   Optimism is rarely in short supply at L'Oreal. but years of relatively sluggish revenue growth at the cosmetics supplier have sapped some of investors' optimism for its stock.   Their worry is that L'Oreal's scale is such that its sales growth will slow even more over the long term, and if it doesn't, it will be because L'Oreal (ticker: 12032.France) has sacrificed profit margins to sustain it.   So L'Oreal's announcement Thursday of better 2006 profits and margins wasn't good enough to lift the shares, when expectations were for still more. It's little surprise that the stock, which at its late-week price around 80 euros a share was trading at about 24 times estimated 2007 earnings, has run into selling pressure. However, that might dissipate quickly.   The reason: L'Oreal's bullishness may prove infectious, particularly because it has raised the 2006 dividend by 18%, to 1.18 euros a share, paying it out of a much more modest increase in earnings. Profit before exceptional items and minority interests rose 12%. Net profit was up only 4.5%, to 2.06 billion euros.   CEO Jean-Paul Agon insists that L'Oreal is on track to hit its medium-term sales-growth target of 6% to 8% in 2007, with relentless growth in emerging markets and lesser gains in mature ones. The disruptions that hit sales in the U.S. retail sector last year shouldn't recur in 2007, he says.   The 1 billion euro improvement in L'Oreal's gross operating profit and tight control of selling, general and administration expenses more than compensated for a 300 million euro increase in advertising and promotional spending. L'Oreal's operating profit margin rose to 16% from 15.6% in 2005.   That extra spending should set L'Oreal up for a good first quarter, at the very least.   The degree to which L'Oreal is managing its business tightly was visible in its strong generation of working capital in 2006. The company is confident that better control of inventory might offset any short-term pressure on its finances as sales accelerate through 2007.   Agon remains resolute in his belief that the company's acquisition of the Body Shop, whose results now are fully integrated into L'Oreal's, was a smart move. Body Shop, he says, is more than just a retailer. He views it as a distinctive brand, positioned between a mass-market and prestige products supplier -- "masstige," to use the industry jargon. There's little evidence the Body Shop is holding back L'Oreal, even if it's too soon to see any major contribution from it to L'Oreal's momentum.   That does leave the trickier issue of L'Oreal's valuation, complicated by its residual stake in drug maker Sanofi-Aventis (SNY). At face value, L'Oreal is trading at a big premium to rivals like Estee Lauder (EL), Avon (AVP), Colgate-Palmolive (CL) and Procter & Gamble (PG), though none has the quite the same profile as the French company. Strip out Sanofi, however, and L'Oreal is trading at its lowest multiple in years.   Profitable growth might be proving to be more of a challenge for L'Oreal than in the past. But if 2007 is the year when M&A activity allows L'Oreal to exit Sanofi painlessly, turning itself into a pure-play cosmetics investment, investors might yet warm to the company's masstigious potential.   ---   Matthew Curtin is a contributor to The Skeptic, a Dow Jones Newswires column on which this European Trader is based.   ---                         DOW JONES GLOBAL INDEXES    Region/  Country     DJ Global          DJ Global          DJ Global     Point      Indexes,           Indexes,           Indexes,      Chg.    % Chg. Headline: Valero Fire May Hike Fuel Prices In Rockies, Beyond -Analysts
Story: AMARILLO, Texas (Dow Jones)--Gasoline and diesel prices may rise in markets supplied by Valero Energy Corp.'s (VLO) McKee oil refinery in Sunray, Texas, following a fire there Friday night, and may even spur higher prices in the broader U.S. market.   "If it is shut for longer than a week it will have a big impact," said one Wall Street analyst, noting that seasonal maintenance has lowered refinery utilization across the U.S. With almost 15% of capacity already off-line, the impact of the McKee refinery outage is more likely to be felt, he said.   The company shut the entire refinery Friday, evacuating all personnel, after a fire began in the propane deasphalting unit of the 158,000 barrel-a-day refinery here in the Texas panhandle.   Late Friday, Valero spokeswoman Mary Rose Brown said the company had taken measures to prevent supply disruption. "Regarding our commercial operations, we have purchased product and made other arrangements to cover our immediate supply requirements," she said.   Still, analysts worried about the market impact. The refinery is strategically located, supplying not only the local area, but also delivering products to the Denver, Phoenix, and Tucson areas through Kinder Morgan's pipeline from El Paso.   "Depending on the extent of the damage at McKee, Denver could be meaningfully impacted on supply," another industry analyst said. Two other refineries which serve that market also have planned shutdowns coming up, the analyst said.   The Suncor refinery in Denver is scheduled to be shut for a turnaround and Frontier Oil Corp.'s (FTO) Cheyenne, Wyoming, refinery is also planning to take its coker off-line in March. Together, the three plants supply roughly 60% to 70% of Denver's refined products.   "If McKee is down for an extended period, Denver will be very tight and margins will likely surge up," the analyst said. The Arizona market will likely see a lesser impact because refiners like Holly Oil Corp. (HOC) and Western Refining (WNR) will likely fill any McKee shortfall from the East, and the pipeline from the Los Angeles refineries to Arizona is not currently full, and could ferry additional refined products to the area.     -By Jessica Resnick-Ault, Dow Jones Newswires; 713-547-9208; jessica.resnick-ault@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 09:55 ET (14:55 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) The Striking Price: A Mixed Message Spells Profits
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Steven M. Sears   When most investors look at the stock market, they see a market of stocks -- not a stock market.   Options strategists see neither.   Instead, they see lines of implied and realized volatility stretching across calendar graphs that tell them how various securities have behaved in the past, and how they may behave in the future.   Like tea-leaf readers, strategists interpret volatility data to reveal options that are trading at premiums or discounts to their historic prices. Sometimes, the analysis finds an index at odds with its components. That is currently true of the Nasdaq 100 Index (ticker: NDX) and its components.   The index's three-month implied volatility is about 16%, compared with a historic volatility of about 13%. The average three-month implied volatility of an NDX component stock is about 27%, compared with a historical average of about 25%.   To options strategists, this discrepancy tells a story about the future stock-price movement for the Nasdaq 100 -- and suggests a trade.   "The individual stock-volatility markets are saying low volatility is here to stay, but the index-volatility market is saying the low volatility is a temporary phenomenon," says Leon Gross, Citigroup's global head of equity-derivatives strategy.   The reason for the disagreement between stock and index volatility are not readily apparent, and does not matter to traders who are attracted to "dispersion trades," as these volatility anomalies are called. These traders, known as volatility arbitragers, believe volatility behaves like a rubber band, and that when it is stretched out, as with the NDX, it ultimately reverts to the historical norm.   To profit from this anomaly, Citigroup advised clients to sell NDX "straddles" -- puts and calls with the same strike price -- that expire in June. This strategy is profitable if NDX volatility remains low, as it has for much of the past year, or if the index continues the sideways trend of the past few months.   "The index has remained richly priced to realized volatility for the past two months," Gross says. "In percentage terms, you're looking at a premium of almost 25%."   The classic dispersion trade is buying straddles on the index's component stocks and selling a straddle on the index. This strategy benefits from low index volatility relative to the volatilities of its components stocks, which occurs if the actual correlation between the stocks is lower than that priced into the options.   But rather than focusing on the index, so far many traders are opting to focus on many of the NDX stocks that Citigroup has identified as having historically cheap options. This list of 27 stocks -- including: Akamai Technologies (AKAM), Altera (ALTR), Amazon.com (AMZN), Biomet (BMET), Cisco Systems (CSCO), ebay (EBAY), Google (GOOG) and Starbucks Coffee (SBUX) -- is useful to investors interested in buying inexpensive options to express bullish or bearish stock views.   In fact, Citigroup's list of cheap options reinforces a growing consensus among investors that there are pockets in the technology sector that may prove profitable, such as Cisco, Google and some hardware and semiconductor stocks.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Story: Home Depot seems to have gotten the message. Blake was given a much smaller pay package, tied far more closely to the stock's performance. Also, the company announced it may sell or spin off the wholesale-supply business, and Batchelder will join the board later this month. Whitworth begged off from filling the seat since his second wife, Fay, is expecting a child later this year and he wants a less hectic work schedule.   Relational has high hopes for Home Depot. Among other things, Whitworth has proposed that the company return some $38 billion, or $19 a share, to shareholders in the next year, either through a massive stock buyback or, for efficiency's sake, a special dividend. It would be financed by $28 billion in net new borrowing, with the remainder coming from the sale of the wholesale unit. With $12 billion in annual sales, that business should garner at least $10 billion.   He says the added debt could be managed easily and would instill management discipline in operations and capital spending. By concentrating solely on its retail operations, Home Depot would be able to boost operating margins by a full percentage point between 2008 and 2010, to around 15% while producing 5% same-store sales growth. Moreover, the reduction in the equity base would magnify the earnings improvement.   As Whitworth told the Home Depot executives in L.A., he sees the company's price-earnings ratio climbing to 18 from a recent 14 after the chain exits the wholesale business and fortifies its retail operations. He thinks the stock could double to more than 80 in the next three years.   That's a tall order, but Relational is used to tall orders, especially when it has $1.3 billion on the line. Headline: Barron's(2/19) Tech Trader: For Biotech, Here Come The Clones
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Bill Alpert   Generic competition for biotechfirms like Amgen and Genzyme drew a step closer Wednesday, when a bipartisan group in Congress introduced a bill to authorize Food and Drug Administration approval of generic biologic drugs. Traditional drugs have had 20 years of government-authorized generic competition, but there's been scarcely any competition for biologics -- those proteins or other fancy molecules typically made in cell cultures of genetically modified organisms. The lack of competition has enabled biotech companies to charge tens of thousands of dollars a year for treatments, creating lucrative businesses from even a small number of sick patients.   High prices for biologic drugs are welcomed by biotech shareholders, but not by health care's payers. The biggest biotech spender is Uncle Sam himself, under the Medicare program, which spent over $3 billion on just three anemia drugs from Amgen (ticker: AMGN) in the fiscal year ended September 2005. So after Amgen's patents expire, the government and private insurers would love to see competitive pricing. In a Thursday conference call Sanford C. Bernstein biotech analyst Geoffrey Porges said: "Amgen is obviously the big target here."   Amgen and the biotech industry's trade group quickly leapt into action after Wednesday's press conference by the biogeneric bill's lead sponsors -- Rep. Henry A. Waxman, Sen. Charles E. Schumer and Sen. Hillary Rodham Clinton. Waxman has been preparing the "Access to Life-Saving Medicine Act" for months, and those who see themselves as biotech's "innovators" were ready. Spokespersons for Amgen warned of the complexities of copying biologic products and urged that any copycat biotech drugs prove their safety in human clinical trials. European regulators took years to develop rules for approving generic biotech products, cautioned Amgen spokeswoman Kelley Davenport.   Backing the biogeneric bill from the get-go were General Motors, which pays the nation's biggest private medical bill, as well as health insurer Aetna. Other endorsers were the generic drug giant Teva Pharmaceutical (TEVA), which has been tooling up to make biogeneric drugs, and pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts (ESRX), which released a study that said the country's annual savings from biogenerics could rise from $3.5 billion to $12 billion over the first ten years.   As Barron's readers well know, some biotech drugs would be easier to copy than others (see "Biotech's New Battlefield," May 22, 2006). Hormones like insulin and human growth hormone are less complex molecules than the much larger proteins of the monoclonal antibodies made by the likes of Genentech (DNA) to fight cancer. Scientists understand the mechanism of action of the simpler biologics; not so, for the more complicated ones.   Human insulin made by genetically engineered critters is a low-hanging fruit, therefore, for the biogeneric ambitions of companies like Wockhardt, the Indian drug company. That's why vendors of recombinant human insulin like Novo Nordisk (NVO) have hightailed it into the sale of modified insulin products that improve upon the natural stuff.   Also toward the easier end of the knockoff scale are enzymes like those produced as "orphan drugs" for rare metabolic disorders by Genzyme (GENZ). Sales in 2006 were $1 billion for the company's cash cow Cerezyme, which treats the genetic disorder Gaucher's disease. That was about a third of the firm's total revenues. Genzyme charges patients hundreds of thousands of dollars a year for its orphan drugs. Yet comparability-testing for copycat enzymes would be fairly straightforward if biogeneric approval rules ever became law . . . and, of course, if patents were not obstacles. Genzyme claims patents for Cerezyme that stretch through 2010 and beyond.   Somewhat harder to knock off are the interferons, like those sold by Biogen (BIIB) and the anemia drugs Epogen and Aranesp sold by Amgen. But there's plenty of incentive for generic firms to try. Amgen's two red blood cell boosters kicked in nearly half of the company's $14.3 billion in 2006 sales, and surely a greater portion of its $2.48 a share profit (including option expenses and other non-cash charges).   There already are potential challengers to the Genzyme and Amgen best sellers -- from Britain's Shire (SHPGY) and Switzerland's Roche Holding (RHHBY), respectively. But those rivals have gone down the lengthy FDA approval process established for a biologics license application. The whole point of generic-drug regulation is to allow copycat versions of a proven drug to get to market more quickly.   The Waxman biogenerics bill proposed last week recognizes that some biogeneric products would require more testing than others, to establish their similarity to the pioneer product. The bill would leave it to the FDA to set the requirements for each product application. By offering a period of exclusivity to the early generic firms, the bill also hopes to motivate generic companies to come up with ways of showing their biogenerics are so very, very similar to the original that a pharmacist could interchange them. Even Europe hasn't figured out how such interchangeability might work, but that's where the pharmacy-benefit managers have extracted the big savings from traditional generic drugs.   Proponents of the biogenerics bill hope to speed its approval by attaching it to an urgent piece of legislation: the reauthorization of the FDA's power to charge "user fees" to drug approval applicants . . . a power set to expire in September. That's probably too ambitious a timetable for the biogeneric bill, which has inescapable complexities, fierce industry opponents and no widespread support among Republicans -- according to Peggy Binzer, a former FDA health attorney now with Washington, D.C.'s McKenna Long & Aldridge, who spoke to Bernstein clients on Thursday's conference call. But Binzer gives 50/50 odds of some kind of biogeneric bill passing by the end of the year, because of the money that Medicare could eventually save with biogenerics.   Once biogenerics became law, the FDA would need a long time to draw up regulations. And even under those regulations, the "comparability" testing of some biogenerics could take years. And of course, patent claims must be put to rest. That long runway gives Amgen and Genzyme time to introduce new drugs. But it would also make the biogeneric game less competitive for those who can afford to play it. Those who've shown an interest include manufacturers like Novartis (NVS), Pfizer (PFE), Teva and Barr Pharmaceuticals (BRL), as well as pharmacy benefit firms like Express Scripts and Medco Health Solutions (MHS).   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:10 ET (05:10 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Electronic Arts: Kicking Off A New Era
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   The launch of the three big new videogame consoles in recent months has been causing as much commotion in living rooms and dens as any pre-game party on Superbowl Sunday.   That's good news for game publisher Electronic Arts (ticker: ERTS), the industry's behemoth and, as it happens, the maker of the hugely popular Madden National Football League games. As consumers snap up new consoles, they're all but certain to reach for the latest games. And those sales could be considerably greater, and more profitable, than much of Wall Street expects.   Sharply boosting demand for games are the new PlayStation 3 from Sony (SNE), featuring cutting-edge technology; the Xbox 360 from Microsoft (MSFT), with great graphics; and Nintendo's (7974.Japan) lively, easy-to-use Wii. At the same time, Electronic Arts, with big sports games covering everything from golf to NASCAR racing, looks well positioned for the coming world of mobile games -- online services for cellphones and other hand-held devices. Electornic Arts has been spending some $200 million a year on developing that field and soon should start reaping the rewards.   "We're at the very beginning of the next very significant growth cycle" for the industry, says Chief Executive Larry Probst, a well-regarded 22-year veteran of the company.   In the last big upswing for videogames, from 2000 through 2004, industry revenues surged 50%. If that happens again, as some expect, Electronic Arts would be the prime beneficiary. The Redwood City, Calif., company is shooting to garner no less than 20% of game sales on each of the 11 main consoles, including the hand-held Gameboy Advanced, where it now holds just 5% of the market.   Over the next few years, a chart of Electronic Arts' earnings growth might rival the excitement of any of its games. The consensus among analysts is for earnings of $2.15 a share for the fiscal year ending in March 2009, nearly triple the profits of the year now ending, according to Thomson Financial. That kind of growth goes a long way toward justifying what is clearly a high price-earnings ratio -- 38, based on estimated earnings for the coming year. Some bulls, in fact, see 2009 earnings as high as $2.30 a share, or a P/E of 22, based on the current stock price.   "If you look through the next couple of quarters . . . you'll get paid in spades" by the stock, says Michael Pachter of Los Angeles-based Wedbush Morgan Securities. He sees the shares climbing from a recent 51 to 65 within 12 months.   Now that the new game consoles and related games have been launched, he points out, the company's steep research and development costs should start to fall. Since Electronic Arts uses cash flow for R&D, both cash flow and earnings per share should swell.   Electronic Arts, which has a market value of $15.5 billion, has a notably strong balance sheet, with $2.6 billion in cash and short-term investments and no debt at the end of December. The company has no dividend, though the possibility of adding one has been "constantly discussed," says Probst. It recently completed a buyback of $750 million of stock, but has no new stock- repurchase authorization.   It's true that Electronic Arts' quarterly reports can be volatile. A series of missed earnings estimates caused David Sandell, portfolio manager of large-cap Leeb Capital Management, to dump the stock in the summer of 2006. "There were enough times the company guided [the market] lower" with projected results to turn him off, he says.   Earlier this month, the videogame maker issued a weaker-than-expected sales forecast for its fiscal fourth quarter. But it met Wall Street estimates for third-quarter profits. At that time, the company announced plans for stepped-up game development for the popular Wii, which has outsold the PS3. At $250, it's about a third the price of the Sony product, and it has attracted gamers and non-gamers alike.   The new Sony platform, thanks to development delays and the steep price, has sparked "a lot of negative buzz," says Stephen Totilo, who covers the gaming beat for MTV News. Still, he says, Sony is "the New York Yankees of consoles" and PS3 ultimately will emerge as the leader.   Electronic Arts has proved nimble over the years at producing popular games for the latest consoles. It has topped all other  publishers in sales for each of the past four years, according to Game Developer magazine.   It all starts with strong sports franchises, especially North American leader Madden NFL 07, featuring sportscaster and former coach Johh Madden. The version for 2006 sold more than eight million copies. Other games are centered on the National Hockey League, Major League Baseball, NCAA football and the National Basketball Association. Though the company pays to license the names, they're cash cows because rosters are updated every year and each new version gets snapped up at release. Electronic Arts has sold more Madden NFL copies each year than the previous year. The company's games typically sell for anywhere from $39 to $59 apiece.   Another big winner -- FIFA Soccer -- is the most popular videogame in Europe, even bigger than Madden is in North America. Game players also snap up Need For Speed, about a street racer grabbing territory from rival gangs, and The Sims, a soap-opera-like game that particularly appeals to girls.   In fact, the company has been  broadening its reach beyond its core demographic of 18-to-30-year-old male videogamers. Its Pogo interactive Website is popular with women and offers puzzles, word games and card games, including solitaire. For $34.99, a consumer purchases a full-year membership to higher-end games that allow multiple players, tournaments and cash competitions.   The new demographic is "aged 3 to 65," says P.J. McNealy, a financial analyst with America Technology Research. Aging baby boomers, he says, are attracted to casual games like chess and checkers, while young kids are hooked on hand-held gaming devices. Children's interest in videogames is so intense that it has created a bit of a backlash from parents and psychologists, who believe the little ones should be playing sports outdoors, not on a console in the den.   But others insist games are good for youngsters. "Well-designed computer games help kids learn innovative thinking," says David Williamson Shaffer, associate professor of learning sciences at the University of Wisconsin-Madison and author of the recently published  How Computer Games Help Children Learn. In this digital age, the games and their consoles are "a profoundly important technology on the order of the printing press, even language," he maintains.   Some videogames can actually help kids exercise. The new Wii (pronounced "we," not "why") comes with a pad on the floor that allows for virtual dance lessons. Or children can swing their arms back and forth with a virtual racket as they play a game of tennis. Features like that have helped make the Wii a sellout.   On average, the Big Three consoles launched recently will have lives of five years before the next versions arrive. McNealy expects Nintendo to wait three to four years before rolling out an updated WII, while the Xbox 360, which is capable of upgrades, will last five years and the PS 3 seven to ten. The PS 2, now sharply discounted, may have another couple of years of life, at least with more price-sensitive buyers.   Electronic Arts has a knack for aiming at the right consoles at the right time. Back in 2001, the company decided to initially make its Harry Potter videogame available on the PS 1, but not on the  PS 2, which was rolled out in October of that year. The rationale was that the oldest child in the house would be playing games on the hot new product, while little brother or sister would get the hand-me-down PS 1. It turned out to be a winning strategy: The company sold more than  10 million  copies of the title, which drew little interest from older teens.   That's not the only way Electronic Arts thinks outside the, well, Xbox. It made $5 million in the latest quarter on ads that grace the billboards of the stadiums and raceways in its videogames. It also sells specialty items like a downloadable football playbook for gamers who want to improve their scores on Madden NFL.   Electronic Arts' revenue from mobile games reached $100 million in the nine months ended Dec. 31, up from virtually nil a year ago. It's sure to keep climbing as celluar networks speed up and handsets get better at displaying games. Fans see this new market eventually becoming huge and attracting an older audience, such as commuters.   Some say "the gaming industry will become as large as the motion-picture industry," says Ken Stuzin, co-manager of Brown Investment Advisory & Trust's large-cap Growth Equity fund and holder of Electronic Arts shares. "Don't let the high P/E frighten you" from buying, he says. "We've seen this cycle before."   Lights! Camera! Joystick! Or as Madden himself might say: "Are you ready for some football?"   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Barron's Online: Small Businesses Bring Big Growth
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Dimitra DeFotis   Legacies die hard on Wall Street, and Principal Financial Group's legacy is the insurance business.   Formed in 1879 as a life insurer for Iowa bankers, Principal and its executives, many of whom started as actuaries, are still based in Des Moines. Insurance remains an important business for Principal, generating about 30% of profits. As a result, some investors dismiss the company's strongly performing stock as little more than an expensive play on a mature business.   But that view doesn't account for the fact that 70% of Principal's earnings come from mutual funds, institutional asset management, and 401(k)s and other retirement plans and services, some of which are growing briskly. The 401(k) business, for example, is still expanding as small companies catch up to the Fortune 500 with retirement offerings, and as 2006 pension-reform legislation encourages greater savings for retirement.   Plus, Principal's annuities should be increasingly attractive to aging baby boomers, whose lifespans can be expected to exceed previous generations'.   Trading near an all-time high, Principal shares reflect some of this potential. But future growth should allow its price-to-earnings multiple to expand and push the stock higher.   "Principal has an attractive portfolio mix that benefits from the increasing longevity of the aging population," says Sterling McMillan, a portfolio manager at Greenleaf Capital Management, which owns the stock. "We believe Principal has the continuing opportunity for steady growth of earnings and revenue that justifies its current multiple."   Principal is the second-largest provider of services for smaller 401(k) plans, with 100 to 1,000 participants. It trails only Fidelity based on the number of plans in that market segment, according to Cerulli Associates, a Boston-based fund consulting firm.   In recent years, Principal has increased assets under management, organic sales and earnings per share by at least 17% annually. Each new dollar in a retirement account boosts margins because expenses don't go up as much. And Principal sends much of that 401(k) money to its own funds.   With December's completion of its acquisition of WM Advisors, a unit of Washington Mutual, Principal Funds has roughly $53 billion under management.   Of course, any correction in the high-flying stock market could hurt Principal's business.   But Chief Executive J. Barry Griswell, who talked up Principal's prospects at a Merrill Lynch conference Wednesday, thinks those fears are overdone.   "We have an incredibly diverse earnings stream. While tied to the equity market, [our] businesses are counter-cyclical," Griswell told Barron's Online. "We are not a pure-play asset manager, but we are not a pure-play insurer, and that may allow us to weather the storm better than competitors."   Asset-allocation products make up roughly a third of Principal's funds. The firm ranks fourth in the U.S. in this category.   Pension reforms approved last year could boost U.S. 401(k) assets by $3 trillion, or more than 50%, by 2008, according to Principal estimates. Many money managers will no doubt compete very aggressively to run those funds, but Principal's strength in asset allocation should give it an advantage: Investors are looking for help in trying to figure out how to balance their holdings of stocks, bonds and cash.   "They make their money managing the mutual funds," says Timothy Call, a money manager at The Capital Management Corp., a Richmond, Va., asset-management firm. "Every dollar in is extremely high margin."   That said, Principal isn't just about money management and retirement: There's still the 30% of earnings that life and health insurance kick in.   Insurance does act as a damper of sorts, since it requires that reserves be maintained to pay claims and annuities. Principal's combination of businesses keeps it from producing the 25% or more return on equity common among pure-play investment managers, says Colin Devine, an analyst at Citigroup. But the rising flow of money into 401(k)s should reduce the company's sensitivity to equity-market movements.   Principal's shares trade at 16.3 times estimated earnings for the next four quarters, according to Thomson Financial/Baseline. Money manager T. Rowe Price, in comparison, trades at 21 times forward earnings, and Franklin Resources at 18.8.   And while Principal trades at a premium to other life and health insurers at 2.2 times book value, it is cheaper than T. Rowe, at 5.4 times book, and Franklin, at 4.3, says Baseline.   If Principal were acquired at an investment-adviser multiple, the stock could rise 35% from current levels, Call says. He thinks a firm such as Merrill Lynch would be a prime contender if Principal were to sell out.   A Merrill spokesman wouldn't comment. Neither would Griswell.   Absent a takeover over the next two years, Principal's shares "could appreciate 20% because of high-teens earnings-per-share growth combined with price-to-earnings multiple expansion," Call says.   Devine at Citigroup raised his price target to $75 this week. That's 18% above the current price. (Citigroup has an investment-banking relationship with Principal.) And Principal's dividend yield is 1.3%.   Of course, if the market tanks, Principal funds could lose popularity and the stock could sell off. But investors in 401(k)s tend to be conservative in their asset-allocation choices and then stick with them. That should keep Principal's assets, combined with the reliability of its insurance premiums and the growth of 401(k) investing, in a healthy state.   And it makes Principal's strength in providing investing services for smaller employers look like a real advantage, since it should continue to pay off for investors.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Programmed To Stumble?
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   The impending leveraged buyout of Univision Communications (ticker: UVN), the leading Spanish-language broadcaster, will produce one of the most debt-laden capital structures of any major LBO in recent years. This heightens the risk for the company's buyers, including Madison Dearborn Partners, Texas Pacific Group and Thomas H. Lee Partners.   The private-equity firms are paying $36.25 a share for Univision, which will result in a total purchase price of $14billion, including debt. The deal is due to close next month. Univision shares traded Friday at $35.95.   As a private company, Univision will carry $10 billion of debt, with the private-equity firms putting up $4 billion of equity. The projected interest costs on that mountain of debt may total around $800 million this year, about equal to the company's 2006 pretax cash flow of $803 million, based on data in a Univision filing. Even assuming some cash-flow growth this year, Univision may produce little or no free cash flow after a projected $92 million in capital expenditures.   "I've never seen a capital structure so levered," says one veteran investor in high-yield debt. Univision's debt is equal to 12.5 times trailing cash flow. Most LBO sponsors try to keep total debt at no more than six to eight times cash flow, while ensuring that annual cash flow equals at least 1.5 times interest expense.   Univision admittedly is a special case. With its strength in the Spanish-language market, the company has been one of the best growth stories in media. The sale price of $14 billion is a stiff 17.5 times 2006 cash flow, double the valuation of big media companies such as News Corp. (NWS) and CBS (CBS).   The Univision deal suggests that the LBO game is getting more crowded --  and more dangerous. Receptive debt markets have allowed LBO operators to get lots of low-cost financing, although the risks have increased along with the funds thrown at target companies. The Univision financing will include a $7 billion bank loan and $1.5 billion of eight-year junk bonds subordinate to that loan.   Bloomberg News reported last week that the bank loan is expected to be "covenant lite;" it will put few financial restrictions on Univision. Even with scant protection, the bank loan is expected to carry a moderate yield premium of about 2.25 percentage points above LIBOR, a key short rate now at 5.35%.   The junk bonds are expected to yield about 9.5%, high by current standards in the junk market, where many bonds yield 7% or less. Considering the risks, investors might not get a great deal, however. Univision will have the option of deferring interest on the junk debt, a reflection of its debt-heavy financial condition. Even with the onerous interest costs, the LBO firms plan to take an annual management fee estimated at $16 million this year.   Moody's gave the Univision junk debt a highly speculative rating of single-B3, and Standard & Poor's weighed in with an even lower rating, triple-C-plus. Moody's cited a risk stemming from the current dispute between Univision and Grupo Televisa (TV) about programming that Televisa provides to Univision, which generates 36% of Univision's ad revenue. "Univision's highly levered capital structure limits flexibility to renegotiate the terms of the contract as part of any resolution of Televisa's litigation," Moody's said.   Given Univision's debt-laden balance sheet, Univision may find some investor resistance when it starts an institutional "roadshow" for the junk deal. If investors balk, it could be a signal that some sanity is entering the overheated junk market.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Insiders, Look Out!
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jonathan R. Laing   With much fanfare, the maitre d' at Rancho Santa Fe's chic eatery Delicias ushered Ralph Whitworth and a guest to a primo table.     The burly, 51-year-old Whitworth is something of a celebrity in San Diego's wealthiest zip code, remembered well in part for a 50th birthday party he threw at Delicias in 2003 for his then wife, Wendy, at which Paul McCartney entertained some 150 guests in return for Whitworth's $1 million contribution to Sir Paul's favorite charity, Adopt-A-Mine. The party garnered headlines in both the U.S. and the United Kingdom.     These days, Whitworth is making news of a different sort, as an activist investor effecting change at some of America's most prominent corporations. His fingerprints, it seems, are everywhere. In early January, Home Depot (ticker: HD) stunned Wall Street by ousting its chairman and CEO, Robert Nardelli, just a month or so after Whitworth's investment firm, Relational Investors, informed the company by letter that it had purchased $1 billion of stock in the home-improvement retailer and wanted changes in the way Nardelli was running it.   Home Depot sources later claimed Nardelli had been pushed out because of his refusal to agree to any changes in his gold-plated employment contract, which guaranteed him total compensation of more than $450 million, including an exit package of $210 million, for six years of work. But Whitworth's saber-rattling played a role.   Nardelli's successor, Frank Blake, has been in touch with Whitworth in recent weeks, even meeting with him in late January at a hotel in Los Angeles. Among other things, the company agreed to give Relational a seat on the Home Depot board, filled by Whitworth's partner, David Batchelder, 57, to head off a threatened proxy fight. Last week, Home Depot appeared to cave in to a key Whitworth demand: that it consider splitting off or selling its wholesale-supply unit, which Nardelli had established to sell construction goods to commercial builders and government buyers.   Whitworth likewise is joining forces with the hedge fund Pershing Square Capital Management in an effort to dump the entire board of directors of Minneapolis-based Ceridian (CEN), a human-resources-management specialist. The two shareholder-activist concerns think the company should split itself up to separate Ceridian's underperforming payroll-processing arm from its fast-growing Comdata unit, which issues and processes gift cards for leading retailers, and stored-value cards that trucking companies use to monitor the spending of their drivers.   In a biting letter sent to Ceridian in early February, Whitworth took new Chief Executive Kathy Marinello to task for refusing to meet with him or other major shareholders. "I'm afraid she wants to keep her empire intact rather than do the right things for shareholders," he told Barron's in a lengthy interview in his San Diego office suite.   Two years ago, Whitworth set his sights on Jay Sidhu, then chief executive of Sovereign Bancorp (SOV), who took extraordinary measures to keep Relational at bay in its attempt to unseat him and install what it considered shareholder-friendly management. In the fall of 2005 the imperious Sidhu sold a 19.8% stake in Sovereign to a big Spanish bank, Santander Central Hispano (STD), without a shareholder vote, in an effort to dilute Relational's stake and pack Sovereign's board with three friendly Santander members.   Sovereign finally caved last March, agreeing to put Whitworth on the board in response to Relational's unrelenting pressure. It took him but six months to turn a majority of the board against Sidhu and get the CEO cashiered. "There was a fair amount of Stockholm Syndrome on the board after years of its domination by Sidhu," Whitworth says. "Now, with new shareholder-friendly management, we're getting the bank ready for sale by sharpening up its return on average assets, net interest margins and balance sheet."   Shareholder activists used to be regarded as kooks by corporate management, to be treated with condescension at annual meetings rather than taken seriously. But all that has changed as impediments to the nomination of outside board members and independent proxy proposals have eased. Relational's success, in particular, owes much to Whitworth and Batchelder's keen understanding of the zeitgeist; in the aftermath of numerous corporate-accounting and stock-option scandals, Wall Street finally is losing patience with lap-dog boards and avaricious leaders, especially at underperforming companies.   Although Whitworth has gained prominence only in the past five or six years, he is no neophyte in the world of shareholder activism. After graduating from Georgetown Law School in 1984, he went to work for T. Boone Pickens' Mesa Petroleum in Amarillo, Texas, helping the fabled corporate raider in epic takeover battles involving Unocal, Newmont Gold and Diamond Shamrock. Though Mesa mostly failed to come away with the prize, its shareholders, chief among them Pickens, generally made decent money by pushing company managements to issue special payments and the like to stave off Mesa's attacks. At Mesa, Whitworth learned the valuable lesson that the gap between a company's share price and its intrinsic worth often is the result of entrenched management taking care of itself at the expense of public shareholders.   In 1986, Pickens put Whitworth in charge of United Shareholders Association, or USA, a lobbying organization the politically ambitious oilman had started. The group pushed to promote corporate democracy and shareholder rights by attacking abusive corporate practices such as greenmail, poison pills, golden parachutes and unequal shareholder-voting rights.   Within two years, however, both Whitworth and his Mesa colleague Batchelder had left the company, disgusted by what they perceived to be Pickens' hypocrisy. On the one hand, Pickens championed shareholder rights, but he also profited at the expense of fellow investors by receiving a personal fee equal to 4% of the value of any acquisition Mesa made. Whitworth remained in charge of USA until he folded the group in 1994, after testifying before Congress and pressuring the Securities and Exchange Commission on behalf of shareholder rights.   Whitworth and Batchelder joined forces in 1996 to form Relational, with an initial investment stake of $200 million from the giant pension fund California Public Employee Retirement System, or CalPERS. Theory now would be put into practice in that most unsentimental of venues, the stock market.   Today Relational has more than $6 billion under management, most of which comes from CalPERS and other public pension funds. The firm charges hedge-fund-like fees, but with an interesting twist that is a legacy of its first CalPERS contract. The firm gets a maximum management fee of 1% of assets, half of what most hedge funds garner. Relational also receives 20% of all winnings above previous high-water marks, but that 20% applies only to performance the company delivers above the total return of the S&P 500.   Relational has delivered commendable performance, though the manager has trailed the S&P 500 somewhat in the past two years. Since inception (on July 1, 1996) through 2006, returns to investors after all fees and expenses have averaged 18.67% a year, compared with 9.14% for the S&P. Returns have been somewhat lower for investors with fully funded accounts, from which Relational plucks capital as investment opportunities arise. Excess funds in these accounts are invested in SPDR exchange-traded funds that mimic the performance of the S&P 500. From July 1, 1997, through 2006, these accounts returned an average of 13.44% a year, versus 6.75% for the S&P.   Relational typically invests in fewer than a dozen stocks at a time, though its dozen or so analysts monitor a universe of some 1,100 companies with market capitalizations of $2.5 billion and above that trade on U.S. or Canadian exchanges. As assets have grown, the firm has found itself muscling into larger-capitalization situations like Home Depot. The average market value of its holdings has risen to around $26 billion.   Relational looks for companies with solid franchises and strong cash flows that are selling at steep discounts to what it deems their true value. The firm tries to close that gap by persuading company directors and management to take various measures to "enhance shareholder value."   The process, which Whitworth euphemistically calls "engagement," follows a precisely calibrated pattern. First, Relational establishes a "toehold" stake in a target of around $100 million or so. Then Whitworth contacts the company, requesting a meeting with management and directors to present Relational's list of proposals to boost shareholder returns.   If the target company proves receptive, Relational quickly will build its position to 5% to 10% of the stock. If the company rejects Relational's overtures, however, the firm typically will act on its always implied threat of mounting a proxy fight and going public with its proposals. Relational adds to its position in a recalcitrant company only as it is able to ratchet up pressure and cause the target to give ground.   Relational often seeks two board seats. "That way, David or I can always have a second to any of our proposals, thus forcing a board vote and making the issue a matter of record," Whitworth says. Yet they would prefer to effect change without going public or forcing their way onto the board. Confrontation, as Whitworth sees it, only leads to additional time and expense.   Key to Relational's game plan is getting companies to hive off units that are underperforming and diluting the parent's earnings and return on equity. Managements often resist such moves, says Whitworth, because they are loathe to admit mistakes. Instead they will ceaselessly tell Wall Street and their directors that a business turnaround is just around the corner. Since executive pay packages often correlate to the sales, bigness confers its privileges.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Distilling Value From A Famous Name
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Andrew Bary   Brown-Forman is no Coca-Cola, but the Louisville distiller similarly has succeeded in turning a quintessential American beverage -- in this case, Jack Daniel's whiskey -- into a lucrative global brand. The company sold about 8.5 million cases of Jack Daniel's in 2005, making it the sixth-largest liquor brand in the world. Last year, it's estimated, sales hit 9 million cases, with almost half coming from overseas.   Here at home, Brown-Forman doesn't get full credit forits marketing smarts and the savvy management of its own well-stocked liquor cabinet, which also includes Southern Comfort, Finlandia vodka, Fetzer wines and Korbel champagne. Its Class B non-voting shares (ticker: BF-B), at 66, are down from a record 82 last March, largely due to mildly disappointing earnings.   The selloff could spell a buying opportunity.   Controlled by the Brown family for 137 years, Brown-Forman has produced some of the best earnings growth in the consumer sector in the past 15 years. "The Browns have been careful stewards of their brands," says Thomas Russo, a partner at Gardner, Russo, Gardner in Lancaster, Pa., which owns Brown-Forman shares. "They have invested wisely abroad to extend their iconic American whiskey into international markets. Jack Daniel's best days are ahead of it."   Fans argue the stock could top 80 in a year. Class B shares trade for 21 times projected profits of $3.10 a share for fiscal 2007, ending April. Brown-Forman no longer trades for a big premium to its chief liquor rivals, Britain's Diageo and France's Pernod Ricard, though its earnings are likely to grow by double digits in coming years.   Brown-Forman's fortunes hinge on Jack Daniel's, which accounts for some two-thirds of profits. The brand is benefiting from a growing consumer preference for liquor over beer, and a predilection among younger drinkers worldwide for bourbon. The easing of restrictions on liquor advertising in the U.S. have helped Jack Daniel's, which became a Nascar sponsor in 2004. The bourbon -- technically, Tennessee whiskey -- was a favorite of Frank Sinatra's, who was buried with a bottle of it. Legend is, Sinatra was introduced to Jack Daniel's by Jackie Gleason. In Animal House, John Belushi's character, Bluto Blutarsky, empties a bottle in about eight seconds.   The global liquor industry has undergone significant consolidation since 2000. Diageo, the maker of Smirnoff vodka and Johnnie Walker scotch, is No. 1, followed by Pernod Ricard, which bought Allied Domecq in 2005 and owns Chivas Regal and Stolichnaya.   At a time when valuable liquor brands command rich prices, Brown-Forman would be a prize acquisition. The company, valued at a digestible $8 billion, would fit nicely with Diageo, which lacks a strong bourbon brand. But the Brown family seems uninterested in selling out. In his shareholder letter in Brown-Forman's 2006 annual report, chief executive officer Paul Varga said: "Our intent is to continue to be a strong, growing and independent company for generations to come."   Varga, 43, added Friday, "We take a long view. We invest in our brands looking out a generation. Everywhere in the world is a growth market for us."   Some say Brown-Forman might consider merging with Bacardi, a family-owned rum maker. That would let Bacardi go public and broaden Brown-Forman's line-up. Ultimately, the Brown family must decide if the company has the global scale to compete with Diageo and Pernod.   Brown-Forman might not exist today, save for its purchase of Jack Daniel's for $18 million in 1956. It has maintained a consistent, tradition-oriented marketing campaign, spent heavily on advertising, invested in overseas distribution and maintained a premium price, now averaging about $20 for a three-quarter-liter bottle in the U.S.   The Street wasn't thrilled that the company agreed last year to buy Mexico's Grupo Industrial Herradura, a tequila maker, for $776 million. The price was rich, and building American distribution for the brand could dilute Brown-Forman's earnings for the next two years.   The Brown family owns about 70% of Brown-Forman's Class A voting shares (BF-A), which trade thinly around 69. The family's economic interest is 32%. There are 57 million A shares and 66 million B shares outstanding.   Brown-Forman reported 92 cents a share in operating profits for its October fiscal quarter -- four cents below expectations, but up 7% from a year ago. Analysts worried Jack Daniel's depletions -- sales from distributors -- rose in the "mid-single digits" for the third straight quarter, after seven quarters of higher growth.   Yet, most consumer companies would love Jack Daniel's sales growth. If it continues -- and there's scant cause to think it won't -- investors will have something lovelier to toast.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.
