Headline: Barron's(2/19) For Auto Workers, A Bitter Pill From Dr. Z
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Jay Palmer   It was mega-shot across the UAW's bow, a warning to the often-militant auto workers union that it should not take too tough a stand in the coming talks that begin this summer over a new three-year contract. That's probably the immediate reason why DaimlerChrysler CEO Dieter Zetsche suggested last week that he may try to split off the ailing Chrysler unit.   Though the market was abuzz with speculation that a sale or a spinoff was imminent, no plausible details of a deal surfaced. A persistent rumor Friday -- that General Motors was in talks to buy Chrysler -- was quickly dismissed by observers in the know. How could deeply troubled GM possibly take on Chrysler's financial burdens, and what good could come of it, anyway?   But clearly something prompted Zetsche to speak out. And he's never hidden his anger over the UAW's refusal to grant Chrysler the same wage and health-care concessions won by Ford (ticker: F) and General Motors (GM). The union has sought to justify its hard line by pointing to Mercedes' strong profits. By raising the possibility of dumping Chrysler, he may have the hammer in the coming talks over wages, plant closings and layoffs.   Any concessions would be a further boon to holders of DaimlerChrysler stock (DCX), which has jumped nearly 40% in the past six month. For one thing, they could help Chrysler revive or at least get healthier. They also could clear the way for an eventual sale or spinoff of Chrysler on better terms than any deal now would fetch. That could be even better news for DCX shareholders.   The market put enough faith in the GM scuttlebutt to lift Daimler's shares more than 4% Friday, to 73. Analysts figure the shares could climb above 80 if Daimler were able to able to get a decent price for Chrysler. But that's a very iffy "if".   The idea of a GM-Chrysler deal certainly strains credulity. "Take your pick -- `the blind leading the blind' or `two wrongs don't make a right.' We ran out of cliches to use," wrote Shelly Lombard of research firm Gimme Credit.   For that matter it's hard to think of any company that might really want to buy Chrysler. One huge turnoff is DaimlerChrysler's vast financial obligations to Chrysler workers, present and retired. The legacy costs -- pen-sions and health care for retired workers -- alone add an estimated $1,000 to the cost of every Chrysler vehicle.   "Even if Chrysler were priced to sell," says one New York money manager, "no half-way sane buyer would be willing to buy if they also had to assume these past and future worker and retiree obligations. But if Daimler had to keep these liabilities on its own balance sheet, why would it bother to sell in the first place? It seems to me that, until Chrysler sorts out its problems with the UAW, and that would not be easy to do, the company is, for all intents and purposes, unsalable."   Truth be told, there was nothing terribly new in the idea of DaimlerChrysler's registering disappointment about Chrysler. Everyone who follows the German-U.S. auto giant knows that the Stuttgart end of the trans-Atlantic operation has been increasingly unhappy about Chrysler virtually since the merger took place in 1998.   The unit posted a $1.5 billion loss in 2006 and more red ink is likely this year. Though Chrysler has had its good years during the Daimler marriage -- earning, for example, a little more than $2 billion in 2005, thanks to the success of the "hemi" V8 engine, the Chrysler 300 and Dodge Magnum -- it's had a lot more downs than ups.   "In our search for the best solution [at Chrysler], we are looking at all strategic options," Zetsche said in his announcements. Senior aides told Barron's that these "options include everything from a partial or total spin-off of Chrysler to even an outright sale of the company."   Says David Cole, chairman of the nonprofit Center for Automotive Research in Michigan: "Getting out of the alliance makes a lot of sense for Daimler and its big German investors, people who want to refocus on Mercedes. The big question is: How?"   Ultimately, Daimler may have to accept a price far below the $38 billion it paid for its U.S. unit. Remember, BMW (BMW.Germany) sold its bleeding Rover car unit for a symbolic $15 in 2000 (before selling its Land Rover SUV operation to Ford for $2.7 billion). Daimler would get a lot more than $15 for Chrysler, but the price would still be marked way down. In the car business, price-cutting moves the metal. In this case, it could also move the stock.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:07 ET (05:07 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Review & Preview Follow-Up: As Art Prices Climb, Sotheby's Stays Hot
Story: (From BARRON'S)   Since we wrote about Sotheby's last fall ("Art Appreciation," Oct. 9, 2006), the stock has gained nearly 12% -- with much of the rally coming in the past month, as the bullish business trends that pushed the shares 69% higher in 2006 remain intact. Shares of the auction house (ticker: BID) now change hands around $38.70, just under the target of around 40 cited in our story.   Sotheby's is not quite the bargain it once was, but in view of the robust art market, its rally is apt to continue.   Sotheby's is trading "as if it is a growth stock, not a cyclical one, and unless the art cycle has disappeared as a result of globalization or climate change or something, it is kind of rich," says Gary Greenberg of London-based Muse Capital. In the short term, however, he thinks momentum could carry the stock into the mid-40s. Sotheby's trades at about a 10% discount to its luxury-brand peers, he says.   The extraordinary growth in worldwide collecting has been fueled by the huge fortunes being made in oil- and commodity-rich countries, as well as the emerging markets of China and India.   In a sign of the times, Sotheby's fall auctions were a resounding success, rounding out another big year that saw $3.6 billion in sales of fine and decorative art, a third more than the company sold in the previous year. There appears to be no letup in the allure of art collecting, as evidenced by some of the auctions held in the current quarter. With eight auctions completed, sales are up 55% from the year-earlier period, which saw a 30% year-over-year rise.   Sotheby's boldly lifted its buyer's commission rates in January to 20% on the first $500,000 and 12% on the balance, marking the second time in as many years it has lifted rates. In 2005, Sotheby's rate rose to 20% on the first $200,000, up from 20% on the first $100,000. Christie's, the market's other dominant force, followed suit. Such is the power that comes from the auction market's duopoly. Sotheby's is the only way for public investors to play this market.   Wall Street expects Sotheby's to earn $1.72 a share in 2006 and $1.97 a share this year. The company will report fourth-quarter results March 7. Investors will be seeking signs it has regained control of expenses, which ballooned in the third quarter as experts in Chinese and Russian art were hired. If costs are indeed under control, Sotheby's shares might exceed all expectations, much like the art market itself.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Driven By A Vision Of Global Growth -2-
Story: Q: Do you like the financial sector overall?   A: Yes, there has been a bit of a run up in price, but banking is a fairly good business if you believe in economic growth because you get the double whammy of fewer loan losses plus credit expansion. We are still underweight financials versus the benchmark weighting.   We are much more attracted to banks that have asset-management businesses. Asset managers have historically been underpriced in the market. With some of the European companies, there is good exposure to financial services and financial products, which is a growth area. We own the two big Swiss banks, Credit Suisse [CS] and UBS [UBS]. They are in the top 10 of our portfolio.     Q: What else do you like?   A: We have a couple of decent positions in U.K. media companies: Trinity Mirror [TNI.UK], which owns the Daily Mirror and a group of regional presses, and Johnston Press [JPR.UK], which also owns regional or community presses. They've been tarred with the same feather as newspapers here, and it's not quite the same situation. Much more of the economics comes from the cover price of the paper and there's less reliance on classifieds.   A lot of these companies are misunderstood. People think the Internet is going to be a huge hog for all advertising dollars. There is no doubt they are going to get a piece of the pie. But that's like saying in early 1900s you should have sold all of your newspaper stocks or in the '40s you should have sold your radio stocks. There are always new forms of media; the good news for media is the pie itself grows at an above-average rate. We also own the French advertiser Publicis [PUB].   One of our top positions is British Sky Broadcasting [BSY] in the U.K. BSkyB has a tremendous pay TV franchise. We wouldn't be so high on satellite TV in other markets, but their position in Britain is strong and getting stronger. They are protecting and expanding their franchise. To offer a triple play of TV, voice and video they bought a high speed Internet provider. Their competition is cable, which is a more fragmented industry in the U.K. with much lower market share.     Q: Those media positions hurt you last year.   A: They hurt us last year, and yet we still did OK. The newspapers have been very poor performers. Publicis has bounced back and continues to perform. It has been a tremendous outperformer within the industry. They've got margins of 16% to 17% and they continue to grow.     Q: What's your current thinking on Japan?   A: On paper, companies are cheap. My issue with Japan has always been finding management teams that are committed to building shareholder value. The average return on equity at Japanese companies, according to Morgan Stanley Capital International, is somewhere around 8% or 9%, compared with the mid-teens for European companies and a little bit above that for U.S. companies. The Japanese market should sell at a discount because stocks there are not as profitable.     Thanks, David.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:08 ET (05:08 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Speaking Of Dividends: 3M Hikes Payout, Again: Steinway Plays A Happy Tune; Guess? Dividend Debuts
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Shirley A. Lazo   Returning cash to its sharehold- ers while investing for growth are top priorities at 3M. "The strength of our operations and our confidence in 3M's future continue to afford us the flexibility to do both," declared chief executive George W. Buckley Monday in announcing the St. Paul company's 49th consecutive annual dividend boost, along with a two-year, $7 billion stock buyback -- the largest in its 105-year history. From 2004 through 2006, 3M (ticker: MMM) returned morethan $10 billion in cash to shareholders via repurchases and dividends.   The new quarterly payout on the common will be 48 cents a share, up from 46 cents, which makes for a current yield of 2.51%. Holders of record Feb. 23 will receive the new distribution March 12, and the stock goes ex-dividend Feb. 21. 3M has been making payouts without interruption since 1916.   The Dow Jones industrials component's 52-week high is 88.35, set May 8. It currently trades a dozen points below that, but is up from its 52-week low, set July 25, of 67.05.   3M's stock price didn't do much in 2006, but bulls expect its solid cash flow, global reach, extensive product roster and high-profile brands -- such as Scotch cellophane tapes, Post-it notes and Thinsulate insulation --  to change that. Soleil Securities analyst Mark Gulley, for example, Tuesday raised his rating on 3M to Buy from Hold and increased his 12-month price target to 86 from 80.   Less ebullient observers prefer to wait and follow the company's efforts to jump-start growth by expanding its manufacturing capacity; 3M is enlarging or building 18 plants around the world. They also want to get a better idea of how 3M will perform under CEO Buckley, who took the helm just 14 months ago (after James McNerney left to head Boeing).   In 2006, 3M netted $3.85 billion, or $5.06 a share, up 24% from 2005, including a gain of about 57 cents from selling off parts of its branded pharmaceuticals business. Revenues, however, were hurt by slowdowns in the U.S. housing market, which affected 3M's roofing-granules business, and in the auto industry. For 2007, 3M pegs earnings at $5.20 to $5.45 a share, including 60 to 70 cents from the rest of the pharmaceuticals-unit sale that closed in January. The company is looking for acquisitions (likely small to midsize deals because of the pricey stock buyback) that add technology or allow it to enter a new geographical area. In 2006, 3M completed 19 acquisitions.   A $3 special dividend and the end of a protracted labor dispute were the sweet sounds emanating Tuesday from Steinway Musical Instruments (LVB). The bonus payout will be distributed on or about March 9 to holders of record Feb. 23. Steinway does not pay regular dividends. The Big Board-listed stock set a 52-week high Jan. 17 of 35.25.   Dana D. Messina, CEO of the venerable Waltham, Mass., company (it's more than 150 years old), said that with no large acquisitions planned for the near future, "the board determined a dividend to be the most appropriate use of funds at this time." Steinway continues to generate significant cash flows and ended 2006 with over $30 million, after refinancing its bonds and paying off both of its term loans. As for the strike, workers from Local 102 of the United Furniture Workers approved a new three-year contract.     Founded in 1981 as a designer-jeans specialist, Guess?'s (GES) product wardrobe now encompasses all manner of trendy, upscale apparel and accessories. The Los Angeles outfit Wednesday declared a 2-for-1 stock split and its first cash dividend. Both are payable March 12 to investors on the books Feb. 26. The split has an ex-date of March 13, while the ex-date for the new quarterly payout -- a presplit 12 cents a share -- will be Feb. 22.   "These actions reflect our confidence in our company and recognize our solid financial performance and strong balance sheet," said Carlos E. Alberini, the company's chief operating officer. Last year was the second in a row in which Guess?'s net doubled. The stock soared to a 52-week high Thursday of 84.58 on the Big Board.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:05 ET (05:05 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Review & Preview Follow-Up: Alcoa Bids Could Top $40 Billion
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Tom Sullivan   If Australia's BHP Billiton or Britain's Rio Tinto hopes to buy Alcoa, the American aluminum giant, as was rumored last week, they might have to pay a lot more than $40 billion -- the price tag attached to the rumors. Sure, that tab would represent a 33% premium to Alcoa's current $30 billion market value, but it doesn't begin to reflect the turnaround afoot at the Dow industrials component.   Barron's has been a fan of Pittsburgh-based Alcoa for some time (see "Alcoa's Shiny Prospects," Aug. 8, 2005, and "Pricing Outlook Bright for Alcoa," Jan. 22, 2007). Yet the stock, for all its gyrations, did little from the date of our first story, when it traded at 28, until this January. Indeed, Alcoa (AA) has returned just 4%, dividends included, in the past five years, compared with North American rival Alcan's (AL) total return of 65%.   Tuesday, Alcoa jumped as much as 10%, to 36.05, on takeover speculation, but ended the week around 34.50, suggesting Wall Street sees no deal in the offing. That would suit John Buckingham, manager of the Al Frank Fund (ticker: VALUX), fine. "The ship is sailing the right course," he says, "but this is not the time to be selling the company."   Buckingham, whose firm owns 162,000 Alcoa shares, understands why BHP and Rio Tinto might be interested in a deal, especially at a bargain price. After all, he says, "the ugly duckling is now a swan." But he views a bid of $55 a share, or about $48 billion, as a much fairer price for Alcoa holders. Alcoa has dismissed the takeover talk, while BHP and Rio Tinto didn't comment.   An acquisition of Alcoa would help both BHP (BHP), which calls itself the world's largest diversified-resources company, and Rio Tinto, an international mining concern, consolidate their positions in the aluminum industry. Aluminum has underperformed other metals, in part because China produces 30% of the world's supply. But the market has found support from commercial construction and the transportation/aerospace sectors, CreditSights said in a recent report.   Investors in Alcoa, which makes Reynolds Wrap, Dura-Bright car wheels and Spout Pouch beverage containers, as well as aluminum for industrial uses, can expect to benefit. The company is likely to earn $3.03 a share this year, compared with last year's $2.96. Alcoa trades for 11.4 times '07 estimates and yields 2%.   In January, Alcoa announced plans to buy back up to 10% of its shares, in part via debt. That prompted credit-rating agency Standard & Poor's to lower its rating on Alcoa to triple-B-plus -- two notches below the rating the company's debt received from rival Moody's Investors Service.   Yet the yield margins, or spreads, on Alcoa's bonds narrowed a bit in active trading after the takeover reports surfaced; the company's 5.95% bonds due 2037 narrowed by three basis points (a basis point is 100th of a percentage point) to 106 basis points over Treasuries with comparable maturities. That's despite talk that the deal might be done as a leveraged buyout.   "It's a doable deal," says Eric Tutterow, managing director at Fitch Ratings, implying Alcoa is not too large to be swallowed. "With a name like that . . . there would be a lot of support in the high-yield and leveraged-loan markets."   A $40 billion acquisition would trump last year's record $39 billion buyout of Arcelor by the Netherlands' Mittal Steel (MT). But Alcoa shareholders could be counting even more millions before any deal is done.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Talk Of Chrysler Sale Heats Up; Alliance Said In Works-Reports
Story: NEW YORK (Dow Jones)--Two days after DaimlerChrysler AG (DCX) said it was considering all options for its Chrysler Group division, signs multiplied that the German company is actively trying to sell the troubled American carmaker, The Detroit News reported on its Web site Saturday.   Several published reports said DaimlerChrysler was in talks with General Motors Corp. (GM) about a possible sale of Chrysler. Industry sources said unidentified private-equity funds also have expressed interest in a Chrysler deal.   DaimlerChrysler and GM declined to comment Friday on the reports. Company sources told The Detroit News that while some talks may be taking place, an outright sale of Chrysler to GM is not a likely scenario, the report said.   Clearly, however, talk of a possible sale or alliance is heating up, the report said.   JP Morgan Chase & Co., DaimlerChrysler's investment banker, has tapped its London-based mergers-and-acquisitions specialist Lawrence Slaughter to spearhead efforts to sell Chrysler, the News reported.   JP Morgan officials were at Chrysler's Auburn Hills headquarters this week and the firm is expected to issue a prospectus to potential buyers fairly soon, the report said.   The possibility of a Chrysler sale has been in the financial markets spotlight since Wednesday, when DaimlerChrysler's supervisory board effectively put the Auburn Hills automaker on the auction block.   Meanwhile, a German newspaper Saturday said the link under discussion would be an alliance rather than a merger.   The Sueddeutsche Zeitung said such an alliance would be modelled on that between Renault of France and Nissan of Japan. Renault owns about one third of Nissan.   An alliance would mean the companies would remain separate entities with possible cross-shareholding, but would act as one company in product development, production and sales, the Sueddeutsche said.   The paper said exploratory talks between Chrysler and GM had begun.   On Friday, DaimlerChrysler shares rose $3.08, or 4.4%, to $73.33 in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock has gained 13.8% in three days and is at a seven-year high.   Reaction to a possible GM deal was less enthusiastic. Shares in the No. 1 U.S. automaker slipped 10 cents to close at $36.34 Friday amid concerns that a GM-Chrysler combination would slow GM's own recovery effort.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 10:50 ET (15:50 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Snow, Wind Shut Roads In Western US; Plane Windshields Crack
Story: DENVER (AP)--Airlines were investigating why windshields on at least 13 planes cracked at Denver International Airport as winds of up to 100 mph whipped through the foothills in the U.S. state of Colorado.   Meanwhile, at least three people in Iowa died Friday night when a Cessna twin-engine airplane crashed during a snowstorm in a field southeast of the Council Bluffs airport, officials said.   The names of the victims haven't been released, and it is possible there is a fourth victim, U.S. Federal Aviation Administration spokesman Tony Molinaro said in Chicago.   According to the National Weather Service, a fast-moving winter storm was pushing through the area when the plane went down, bringing wind gusts of up to 53 mph, snow and poor visibility.   Officials couldn't say what caused the crash and didn't know if weather was a factor.   In Colorado, several major highways that were closed Friday due to blowing snow and whiteout conditions reopened, though some mountain sections remained closed Saturday.   The storm system that brought nearly a foot of fresh powder to ski resorts, was expected to move out of the state Saturday.   SkyWest Airlines reported cracked windshields on eight planes that were taking off or landing Friday as winds gusted up to 50 mph, spokeswoman Marissa Snow said. One plane's windshield cracked while it was airborne.   "Only the outermost layer was affected," Snow said of the windshields, which are made from multiple layers of glass.   SkyWest, a regional carrier for United Airlines (UAUA), said the planes involved were the Embraer EMB120 Brasilia and Bombardier Canadair Regional Jet, though she didn't immediately have numbers.   Two Frontier Airlines Airbus planes had their windshields crack while airborne, while two other windshields cracked while at the gate, airline spokesman Joe Hodas said.   In all instances, the planes returned to the airport and/or made it to the gate safely. No emergencies were declared and no injuries were reported.   Hodas said it was unclear whether the high winds were to blame.   "It's not exactly unusual weather for Denver," Hodas said. "We don't know what it is... It's kind of a mystery at this point."   Spokesman Steve Snyder said windshields cracked on several different makes and models of airplanes from several airlines, though he didn't immediately know which and how many. None of the pilots reported flying debris, Snyder said.   "Everybody is fairly baffled by it," Snyder said.   At least 55 flights were canceled and others were diverted.   In southern Wyoming, parts of a major highway were closed between Cheyenne and Laramie because of windblown snow driven by gusts over 50 mph and icy patches.   Before the highway was closed, the driver and passenger of a tractor-trailer were killed in a crash at Laramie, the highway patrol said.   In Pennsylvania, the last of hundreds of motorists stranded on a 50-mile  stretch of a major highway were freed Friday, but several highways remained shut as crews struggled to clear ice and snow following a monster storm that has been blamed for at least 24 deaths in the Northeast and Midwest.   Gov. Ed Rendell apologized for the state's "totally unacceptable" handling of the storm and a highway tie-up, which stranded hundreds of motorists for as long as 24 hours. He blamed an "almost total breakdown in communication" among state agencies.   State Transportation Secretary Allen D. Biehler said I-78 and large portions of I-81 and I-80 would remain closed so workers could clear them.   At least 24 deaths were blamed on the storm system and accompanying cold: six in Ohio; three in Nebraska; two each in Illinois, Indiana, New York, New Jersey and Delaware; and one each in Missouri, Pennsylvania, Virginia, New Hampshire and Louisiana.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 06:57 ET (11:57 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Valero Fire Shuts Texas Refinery; At Least 19 Hurt
Story: HOUSTON -(Dow Jones)--Valero Energy Corp. (VLO) shut its McKee, Texas refinery Friday after an explosion and fire rocked the tiny West Texas town and injured at least 19 workers.   "The fire at the Valero McKee refinery in Sunray, Texas has subsided substantially, but it is not extinguished," Valero spokeswoman Mary Rose Brown said in a statement released right before 10:30 p.m. CST Friday.   The latest statement put the number of worker injuries at 19, up from 3 in Valero's previous statement.   The fire followed a large explosion Friday afternoon at the 158,000 barrels-a-day refinery, which created a giant black plume of smoke that could be seen 60 miles away, The Associated Press reported.   For Valero, the McKee incident is its third fire in a week, following two smaller fires at its Delaware City, Del. refinery.   Valero, which grew rapidly over the last seven years from an obscure San Antonio enterprise into the nation's largest refiner through acquisitions, has also reported fires in at least four other plants since May 2006, in addition to receiving a harsh report from federal safety regulators over two November 2005 fatalities at the troubled Delaware plant.   Compared with some of the other fires, which have occurred in sites in St. Charles, La., Texas City, Texas, Corpus Christi, Texas and Quebec City, the McKee incident appears to be of a materially more serious nature; it is the only incident to lead to the shutdown of a plant.   But the McKee incident comes at a relatively benign time in terms of petroleum inventories. Commercial stockpiles of both gasoline and distillate for the week ended Feb. 9 were above the upper end of the average range for this time of year, according to the latest data from the Department of Energy.   Brown said Valero has purchased product "and made other arrangements to cover our immediate supply requirements." Completely shutting a refinery down is rare in the oil industry.   When BP PLC (BP) suffered a major explosion in March 2005 at its Texas City refinery, 15 workers died, but the incident had virtually no immediate impact on supply, because most of the key units of the refinery were unaffected.   It is unclear how long McKee will be off-line for an incident that is far less calamitous in terms of its impact on human life.   At McKee, Valero evacuated all plant employees and contractors Friday after the fire began, Brown said. The incident is believed to have started in the propane deasphalting unit, which processes residual fuel at very high temperatures.   Valero sent one contract worker and two company employees to a burn center at the University Medical Center in Lubbock.   The contract worker is in "stable" condition, while the two employees have "moderate burns," Brown said.   "Sixteen other individuals went to the local hospital and all but four were seen and released," Brown said. "The four individuals remaining in the hospital are reportedly being treated for a variety of non-burn-related concerns such as chest pains, anxiety and stress."   Valero sent two planes from its corporate headquarters in San Antonio with support teams, supplies and other resources, Brown said. Emergency response team members from other Valero refineries are also on the way to provide support, she said.     Valero Trying To Improve Reliability     A darling on Wall Street for its role in helping to revive the once-moribund refining industry, Valero has made a name for itself by acquiring under-capitalized, sometimes troubled plants, and boosting performance with additional investment.   Speaking to analysts on a Feb. 1 conference call, Chief Executive Bill Klesse described the company's operating record as "excellent," given that many of the plants acquired had been starved for capital.   "So if you look at our overall ... hand we were dealt, it's tremendous," he said. At the same time, Klesse said the company has a five-year strategic goal of improving its ranking in the widely-watched Solomon survey from the fourth-quartile to the first-quartile.   The Solomon survey benchmarks refining companies against each other in terms of refinery reliability, maintenance and energy use. Klesse said Valero could save $1 billion if it reaches its goals.   The McKee incident comes immediately on the heels of  a pair of fires at the Delaware refinery, which also suffered some major problems under its prior owner, Motiva Enterprises LLC. Tuesday, Valero reported a small fire in the crude unit of its 210,000 barrel-a-day Delaware refinery. The same plant also suffered a fire in its hydrocracker unit Feb. 9.   In November, the U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigations Board sharply criticized Valero after two workers were asphyxiated inside a nitrogen-filled confined space in November 2005.   "This accident is a telling example of improper entry into a confined space, and we found that workers are not adequately warned that hazardous atmospheres might exist around unsealed confined space openings," CSB Board Member John Bresland said in a news release.   Valero vowed to implement the CSB's recommendations.   (Beth Heinsohn in New York contributed to this story.)   -By Jessica Resnick-Ault and John Biers, Dow Jones Newswires; 713-547-9208; jessica.resnick-ault@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:22 ET (05:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: India's Gandhi Lays Foundation For Airport Modernization
Story: NEW DELHI (AP)--Sonia Gandhi, the head of India's ruling coalition, laid the foundation stone Saturday for an ambitious plan to modernize New Delhi's decrepit, overcrowded airport.   Authorities are planning a new, modern terminal to handle both international and domestic traffic, and a third runway to ensure that the airport can better cope with an ever-increasing tide of air traffic.   India's booming economy has spurred the aviation industry with an increase in carriers and passengers, but its existing airports - particularly in Mumbai and New Delhi, which handle the majority of India's air traffic - have struggled to cope.   Gandhi said her government was determined that the economy - growing at more than 8% annually in recent years - wouldn't be held back by poor infrastructure.   "We are committed to see that infrastructure does not remain a bottleneck in the progress of the socio-economic development of the country," Gandhi said, adding that she hoped the construction of new airports would create thousands of additional jobs.   The new terminal and runway, to be built at a cost of some $1.5 billion, are the first phase of a modernization plan that will eventually see the airport able to handle up to 100 million passengers a year and accommodate the new generation of aircraft including the Airbus A380 superjumbo, organizers said.   The current airport was designed for 12 million passengers a year, but now handles more than 16 million.   "With the completion of this airport, Delhi will boast of a world class airport, which would not only cater to the growing aviation traffic, but will also serve as a benchmark for other airports to follow," said Srinivas Bommidala, the managing director of Delhi International Airport Ltd., or DIAL, a joint venture between India's GMR and Germany's Fraport AG (FRA.XE), chosen to privatize the airport.   The new terminal, which will be able to handle some 37 million passengers annually, is expected to be completed by 2010 when New Delhi is scheduled to host the Commonwealth Games.   Currently passengers at New Delhi's separate international and domestic airports often face long delays in cramped uncomfortable conditions with minimal facilities.   Planes often are forced to circle the airport for long periods or wait in long lines on the runway as harassed air-controllers try to juggle more aircraft than the airports were designed to handle.   The new terminal will include restaurants, shopping areas and entertainment facilities, and modern communication equipment for business travelers, DIAL said in a statement.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 06:15 ET (11:15 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Big Four Lift Makers Face GBP673 Mln EU Fine - Report
Story: LONDON (Dow Jones)--The world's biggest lift manufacturers are bracing themselves for a record fine from the European Commission that could amount to almost GBP673 million for alleged price-fixing activities, the Times reports Saturday, citing industry sources.   The paper says that according to industry sources, some evidence of cartel-like behavior had been investigated in German and the Benelux countries, but insisted that this didn't amount to Europe-wide price-fixing.   Complaints from smaller rivals are believed to have led to the launch of an inquiry nearly three years ago into the so-called "big-four" lift manufacturers: United Technologies Corp's Otis Elevators, based in the U.S. and Paris; Schindler Group of Switzerland; ThyssenKrupp (TKA.XE) of Germany and the Helsinki-based Kone Group (KNEBV.HE).     Newspaper Web site: http://www.timesonline.co.uk   -London Bureau, Dow Jones Newswires; +44 (0)20 7842 9330     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 05:48 ET (10:48 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Ahold Unit Stop & Shop: Union Agrees To Talk Next Week In US
Story: BOSTON (AP)--The labor contract for 43,000 U.S. workers at Dutch-owned Stop & Shop will expire without a new deal, but talks are scheduled to resume next week and the union has agreed not to strike before then, the supermarket chain said Saturday.   Members of three of the five United Food and Commercial Workers locals that are negotiating as a group voted to authorize a strike if no settlement was reached when the current three-year contract expires at 12:01 a.m. EST Sunday.   But the sides scheduled more negotiating sessions Tuesday through Thursday, and the unions agreed they will not strike while talks are ongoing, said Stop & Shop spokeswoman Faith Weiner.   "It means both sides are committed to the process and both sides are working toward an agreement," Weiner said.   Terms of the current contract will remain in effect past midnight, Weiner said.   Richard Charette, president of Local 1445, didn't immediately return several calls for comment.   Negotiating sessions between the UFCW and Quincy, Mass.-based Stop & Shop were held Saturday at the Hilton Hotel in Mystic, Conn. Negotiations began in mid-December and have focused on health care costs and retirement benefits.   Earlier Saturday, Charette described talks as "getting uglier and uglier."   Stop & Shop, owned by the Dutch conglomerate Royal Ahold NV (AHO), is negotiating with the UFCW's Local 1445, covering workers in eastern and central Massachusetts; Local 328, covering Rhode Island and southeastern Massachusetts; Local 1459, covering western Massachusetts; and two units representing Connecticut workers, locals 371 and 919.   The locals represent workers at 231 stores. Workers in New York, New Jersey and New Hampshire are covered under separate contracts.   The two locals that have yet to take strike votes - locals 1445 and 328 - were scheduled to do so late Sunday morning. If the strike-authorization measures pass, union leaders could call a strike at any time.   Charette said he's confident the two locals also would vote to authorize a strike.   "We're in lockstep," he said of the five locals. "We're committed."   Stop & Shop placed advertisements in newspapers last weekend saying it was opening hiring centers at hotels to recruit potential replacement workers.   Stop & Shop currently covers 100% of its union employees' health-care premiums, although employees cover co-payments and deductibles. In the current negotiations, the company wants employees to cover a portion of the premiums.   The union also objects to the company's plan to begin switching new hires from a defined benefit pension plan to an employee-funded retirement plan. The union says the retirement plan offers less financial security.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 16:22 ET (21:22 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Review & Preview Follow-Up: WebEx Is Staying Ahead Of The Crowd
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Mark Veverka   Ever since the success of Salesforce.com's (ticker: CRM) initial public offering in 2004, Subrah Iyar, the CEO of rival WebEx Communications, has argued that WebEx is much more than an online-meeting facilitator, and should be valued as such. But so far, the company is providing reliability and scale that others can't seem to match.   "We see Web collaboration as the 'killer app' over the Internet, and we are the best in class at delivering that service," Iyar says.   One fan, software analyst Peter Goldmacher of Cowen, calls WebEx "the most interesting company in the software space." Headline: Barron's(2/19) The Trader: Bernanke's Valentine Wins Over Wall Street
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Kopin Tan   The middle week of February can be a treacherous minefield of heightened anticipation and unrequited desire. With stocks hovering at a historic high, the potential for disappointment seems substantial. But testifying before Congress, the Federal Reserve chairman Ben Bernanke painted a picture of slow but steadfast economic growth, with inflation under control, and tentative signs of stability in the wobbly housing market.   For investors worried that the Fed may have to raise interest rates to curb prices, the firm, reassuring message proved endearment enough. Stock and bond markets rallied. The broad Dow Jones Wilshire 5000 index pushed to a seven-year high, and on Wednesday, the Dow Jones industrials, transportation and utilities averages surged in sync to record closes for the first time since 1998.   The jubilation faded a little by Friday after economic data showed housing starts declining in January to a nine-year low, and industrial production falling for the fourth time in five months. But with oil prices under control and the bond market calm, profit-taking in the stock market proved shallow and half-hearted.   The Dow Jones Industrial Average ended the week up 187, or 1.5%, at 12,768 -- its biggest weekly gain in three months. It's up 2.4% this year. The Standard & Poor's 500 Index climbed 17, or 1.2%, to 1,456, a 2.6% rise this year.   The Nasdaq Composite Index was bogged down Friday when Microsoft (ticker: MSFT) told investors to temper their revenue expectations for its Vista operating system. But it still ended the week up 36, or 1.5%, to 2496. The Russell 2000 Index of small stocks rose 11, or 1.4%, to another record close at 818. It is up 3.9% this year.   For all the by-now familiar arguments why this bull run has become extended, the market has continued to trudge steadily higher. To be sure, technology's unconvincing run in the face of already-diminished expectations could unfurl into a red flag, and the market's subdued risk forecast and comfortably bullish tilt aren't ideal. But signs of its long-term strength also cannot be ignored.   On Thursday, even as the rally's momentum flagged, a mere four stocks sank to new lows at the New York Stock Exchange. In prior instances when the Dow industrials, transportation and utilities averages have hit simultaneous peaks, the blue-chip benchmark would add an average 2.5% over the ensuing three months and 6% over six months, notes Birinyi Associates.   Meanwhile, a steady stream of deals and buyers circling Alcoa (AA) all point to abundant liquidity and faith in continued economic strength. The argument that stocks aren't yet wildly overpriced also finds support in the popularity of share buybacks. Costco Wholesale (COST), subject of a bullish Barron's cover story a week ago, rose 2 to a record close near 58 amid speculation that the company will use proceeds from a $2 billion bond deal last week to buy back shares. Costco has no need to issue debt because it's sitting on $2 billion in net cash. Some Street analysts, including UBS Securities' Neil Currie, have urged Costco to get more aggressive with its buybacks.   So what can investors expect with the Fed on hold? Conventional wisdom has investors clamoring for a rate cut, but the market has stumbled in prior stretches of Fed pauses that ended with rate cuts. In contrast, the S&P 500 has rallied in eight out of nine prior Fed pauses that ended with rate hikes, notes Birinyi analyst Paul Hickey. The football analogy: Wouldn't you rather have a healthy running back who takes a prolonged breather at half-time or one who requires a cortisone shot (rate cut) to make it through the second half?   The roster of top performers so far this year is brimming with cyclical stocks that do well when the economy charges ahead -- not exactly a picture of a market waiting for Bernanke to ease up and go soft.     It operates in a world of bright sounds and vivid images, but Sony's (SNE) stock has been dull and flat for so long a recent uptick warrants a closer look.   Consider this picture: The Japanese conglomerate's American depositary receipts have pushed above their 50-day and 200-day averages, and last week's 7% rise nudges their year-to-date gain to 23%. A push to cut expenditure at its semiconductor unit, and market-share gains in LCD televisions gave investors some fresh hope.   Sure, predictions of a Sony revival have been consistently premature, and the electronics giant -- once the only name in portable music -- has become a cautionary tale about squandered opportunity. An unwieldy empire stretching from movies and music to financial services and insurance also makes it a symbol of bloat. But its push to improve efficiency will eventually pay off, and investors' decade-long disregard hints at the potential upside should they come around.   "Nearly everyone hates it, nobody appears to have done any work on it, yet the stock continues to show technical improvement," says Natexis Bleichroeder's technical analyst John Roque, who for months has tried to draw skeptical clients' attention to Sony's brightening chart.   Investors' exhausted patience may well be another factor in Sony's favor. With ADRs trading near 24 times forward earnings, and pressure to deliver better profits, expectations continue to increase for management to finally dismantle Sony into units that ought to be worth far more than the elephantine whole.   Credit-Suisse, for example, says the sum of Sony's parts would value its ADRs at 64 -- 22% above where they trade today.     Like sweaters and scotches, coal stocks become more popular as the mercury dips. After suffering through the warmest December in decades, coal producers have rallied sharply as a cold snap grips the northeast in its frigid hold.   Consol Energy shares (CNX), in particular, have surged 15.3% since Jan. 3 -- five times the broad market's rise and well ahead of peers like Peabody Energy (BTU), Arch Coal (ACI) and Massey Energy (MEE). Even the red-hot Select Materials SPDR Fund (XLB) rose just 9.6% over the same period.   It wasn't just the cold, of course. The Pittsburgh company's eastern U.S. stronghold and an 82% stake in a growing gas business augur well. And while coal has fallen sharply from about $58 a ton to $40 over the past year, Consol could be insulated from further short-term swings, having committed much of its 2007 production at average prices near $40.   But with Consol's hot streak comes vulnerability to a short-term pullback. After it reported fourth-quarter earnings in late-January that beat the Street's estimates, a few analysts trimmed their 2007 and 2008 earnings forecast. Among the concerns: further coal price weakness, margin pressures, and recently-concluded union negotiations that Credit-Suisse analyst David Gagliano reckoned could drive unit costs up 5%. Another inconvenient truth: warmer weather, and slower rate of inventory depletion at customer utilities companies, will pressure negotiations for future coal delivery.   Coal producers have begun to shut mines to control inventory glut, but the boost to coal prices will take time. The use of coal for electricity is projected to increase over the longer term, but that depends largely on coal staying cheap relative to other fuel sources. Consol's revenue growth is flat, and the sell-side's optimistic bent -- none of the 17 analysts rate it Sell -- suggests an already well-plumbed bull case.   Placing short bets in this rising market can be a chilling experience, and increased takeovers of commodity producers can leave short sellers cold. That's why anyone eyeing a Consol correction might be better off buying puts, as Pete Stolcers notes on his www.oneoption.com blog. Buying puts risks no more than the premium paid, and thanks to options' leverage, a shallow stock pullback can produce larger put gains. With Consol shares at 35, the March 35 puts were trading at $1.25.   Last week, coal producers were one of the few groups to edge lower even as the market advanced. No coincidence that the weather forecast calls for a thaw at last, with Northeast temperatures expected to climb enough to register the promise of spring.   ---   E-mail: kopin.tan@barrons.com   ---                       VITAL SIGNS                                Friday's        Week's     Week's                                 Close        Change     % Chg. Headline: Valero Says McKee Fire Damage Primarily Contained To One Unit
Story: DUMAS, Texas (Dow Jones)--A fire that began Friday primarily damaged a single unit at Valero Energy Corp.'s (VLO) McKee refinery in Sunray, Texas, a spokeswoman said Saturday.   "Initial reports indicate that the major damage to the refinery was largely confined to the Propane Deasphalting Unit and adjacent piping systems," Valero spokeswoman Mary Rose Brown wrote in an emailed bulletin on Saturday. The unit, where the fire started, operates at extremely high temperatures.   "We do not yet know the full extent of the damage, the required repair time or the estimated production impact," she said.   Although the fire has been essentially extinguished, and flames are no longer visible here, the plant remains shut, Brown said. Emergency crews have entered the plant, but police are still blockading a two-mile buffer zone around the refinery.   Environmental tests by state and federal authorities concluded this morning, and those officials have now left the plant, Brown said. The company is still conducting its own investigation into the incident, as are two other federal agencies.   The U.S. Chemical Safety and Hazard Investigation Board and the Occupational Safety and Health Administration are both looking at the incident in part because of the injuries that resulted from the fire. Two of the individuals who were transported to a Lubbock, Texas, burn center are now listed in good condition and may be released as early as Sunday, Brown said. The third individual in the burn center is listed in critical but stable condition, she said.   The 158,000-barrel-a-day refinery is located about 50 miles from Amarillo, Texas.     -By Jessica Resnick-Ault, Dow Jones Newswires, 713-547-9208; jessica.resnick-ault@dowjones.com     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 16:18 ET (21:18 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Up & Down Wall Street: Goldilocks In Drag
Story: (From BARRON'S)     By Alan Abelson   The dirty little secret is out: Goldilocks sports a beard. A nice tidy number, to be sure, but whiskers, nonetheless. Who ever would have dreamed it?   We sure didn't, before Ben Bernanke braved winter's icy worst last week and trudged up Capitol Hill to give Congress his obligatory spiel, bringing the assembled anthropoids up to date on the state of economy. His message -- everything is fine and dandy, not too hot and not too cold, and likely to stay that way -- resonated less in Washington than on Wall Street, where it powered stock prices to their strongest gains of this promising new market year and, in the process, lifted the venerable Dow to an all-time record high.   Truth is, we always feel sorry for Fed chairmen as they dutifully perform this thankless chore. And to make matters worse, they have to do it twice, because congressmen are slow listeners. The late Molly Ivins' marvelous crack about the Texas legislature -- you know when it meets because every village in the state is missing its idiot -- has more than passing relevance to Congress in session. And nothing befuddles our representatives as much as the rudiments of economics and finance.   While he came to testify prudently armed with a full complement of caveats -- comforting cautions to the effect that inflation is relatively quiescent, but rest assured, the Fed is not indifferent to the possibility of a flare-up, and the decline in housing is something to keep a solicitous eye on -- he was, as the stock market was quick to grasp, essentially upbeat.   He had soothing forecasts for unemployment and the economy and even his concerns about inflation and housing were tempered by assumptions that the former would likely ebb and the latter might be finding some sort of footing.   Mr. Bernanke is more straightforward in both demeanor and speech than his predecessor, which admittedly isn't saying much, but still is something. And he appears more flexible, another happy contrast. But he also seems, like the academic he was for the bulk of his adult life before turning elevated bureaucrat, to have blind trust in the increasingly dubious soundings taken by government data gatherers (the standard inflation measures are a good example) rather than putting his ear to the ground.   Getting more atuned to what's happening in the real world rather than depending on the sight bytes spat out by some anonymous computer modeler would give Mr. Bernanke a better fix on the way things are. It also might save him the chagrin of having his optimism, however tepid, look a bit silly less than 24 hours after he expressed it.   Two cases in point: The latest weekly numbers on new claims for unemployment insurance showed an inordinately sharp rise that may or may not prove to foreshadow a trend, but obviously doesn't spell improvement. And January housing starts, it was disclosed on Friday, fell with a heavy thud, by 14.3% from the previous month, to 1.4 million units (a seasonally adjusted annual rate), the most enfeebled showing in 10 years and down a startling 37.8% from January '06.   Moreover, even as Mr. Bernanke was gently stroking his congressional audience with his matter-of-fact optimism, the latest figures on inventories, industrial production, capital flows and retail sales were prompting an agonizing reappraisal of the economy's recent past and making it inevitable that the 3.5% preliminary estimate of gross-domestic-product growth for the fourth quarter is due for a buzz cut, to 2%-2.5%.   They also suggest, along with other chilling readings -- like the palpable dip in consumer confidence -- that Mr. Bernanke may have to significantly amend his Goldilocks scenario next time he meets with Congress. Maybe something a touch morose from the Brothers Grimm will be more the ticket.   We don't want to be too hard on Mr. Bernanke; he's still something of a rookie playing chairman, having just wound up his first year on the job. And unlike Mr. Greenspan, he doesn't seem to have the makings of a contrary indicator. But off his early performance, he may well turn out to be at best a lagging one.     Although he didn't quite capture the attention of the world at large and investors in particular as did Mr. Bernanke's congressional performance, another illustrious personality also proved something of a cynosure last week and even had a bit of an impact on the stock market. Not to keep you in suspense (and, for all we know, of course, you've not been in suspense at all but may have dozed off before the end of the last sentence), we're talking about Steve Ballmer.   Mr. Ballmer holds down a job that arguably is at least as critical to our economic health and well-being as Mr. Bernanke's -- Ballmer's the CEO of Microsoft. And last week, he gathered together a group of analysts who cover that software colossus to fill them in on the recent debut of its new version of Windows, dubbed Vista, and what the future holds in store for it and his company.   As even the most unreconstructed Luddite is aware, Vista was, as Mr. Ballmer described it, the proud subject on Jan. 30 of the "biggest launch in software history" (that quote really belongs in capital letters but we fear it'd look funny on the page). And since in the world of computers, there is no such thing as a free launch, Vista's grand introduction set back Microsoft a pretty bundle (fortunately, Microsoft is a true corporate Croesus, with a cool $29 billion, give or take a few bucks, in the till -- and not a spec of long-term debt).   Money, it turns out, can buy everything -- except a boffo launch of a new software product. The electronic retailers primed to accommodate hordes hungry for Vista banging on their doors too often, instead, found the thin ranks of their sales help outnumbering those of their customers. Kind of like throwing a party and the guests all show up disguised as invisible people.   Now, we don't want to give you the impression that Vista has been a total dud. It hasn't been, except in terms of living up to extraordinarily extravagant expectations whipped up by all the hoopla. Despite the eerily muted opening day (all the noise pretty much was supplied by the company's poobahs and their subalterns), sales should gradually gather strength as this year rolls on and next year, as well. But, pure and simple, it grieves us to say, Vista doesn't stack up as the mighty blockbuster investors and geeks alike supposedly had been panting for.   Dealng with the usual fawning analytical audience, Mr. Ballmer in his remarks adroitly managed the tricky task of tamping down overexuberance without completely dissipating the glow with which the strenuous advance promotion had enveloped the product. He ran through in commendably no-nonsense fashion the high points of Vista's promise and potential and examined briefly and in broad outline the various markets for it. And, while inevitably optimistic (he is, remember, the CEO), he also, in so many words, cautioned against anyone out there being "somewhat too bullish."   He also sounded distinctly wary of the idea of Vista triggering a great boom for PCs. On that score, he persuasively cited the lack of buoyancy in the stocks of HP, Dell and Intel as arguing against such a notion. He does anticipate "a small surge" in personal-computer purchases, but nothing resembling a boom.   Investors, we suspect, were right to respond coolly to Mr. Ballmer's remarks. They certainly weren't the kinds of comments to get the bulls pawing the ground. What happens from here on to the shares obviously depends on how much enthusiasm (read: sales) Vista is able to whip up. On that, the jury's still very much out.   Fred Hickey, proprietor of the High-Tech Strategist and treasured Roundtable member, had very low expectations for Vista and, as far as he's concerned, they've already been fully met. As is not uncommon with Fred, he put his money where his mouth is, buying put options on Microsoft ahead of the product's splashy introduction, and has the profits to prove it.   We chatted with Fred on Friday, and he remains very much of a mind, as he wrote earlier this month in his newsletter, that Vista is "not an epic disaster for Microsoft" because "ultimately, businesses and consumers will resume their regular upgrade patterns and buy PCs that come pre-loaded with Vista." However, he's convinced its effect on the "PC food chain" stacks up as another and very much sadder story.   Spurred in part by a study commissioned by Microsoft that concluded Vista would generate $72 billion in related hardware, software and service revenue, Fred relates, what he calls the PC food chain --  distributors, resellers and solutions providers -- went wild and hugely overbuilt in preparation for a post-Vista release boom that is clearly not coming.   The result, sighs Fred, is that through the length and breadth of the industry, from semiconductor companies to electronic retailers, there has been a massive inventory build-up -- which, he contends, is a prelude to a disaster. He suspects that the first tremors of real trouble will be felt a few weeks hence, when some dismal earnings forecasts begin to seep out.   What confounds him and could greatly exacerbate a collapse in techs is that investors continue bullish on them despite six long years of underperformance by the sector. Besides Microsoft, his most recent published list of stocks he's negative on includes Best Buy, CDW, SanDisk, Texas Instruments, Lam Research, KLA-Tencor, Nvidia, Research in Motion, Apple, Microchip Technology, STMicroelectronics, Amazon.com, International Rectifier, Dell, Novellus Systems, Xilinx, Motorola, Applied Materials, NetLogic Microsystems and Fairchild Semiconductor.   Looking over that abundant roster, it occurs to us it might have been more efficient simply to list the tech stocks Fred's not negative on.   ---   For Barron's subscription information call 1-888-BARRONS ext. 685 or inquire online at http://www.barronsmag.com/subscription/subscription.html.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:09 ET (05:09 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Barron's(2/19) Insiders, Look Out! -2-
Story: Relational has garnered windfall gains over the years by encouraging companies to face up to reality and dump poor performers. As a director of Mattel (MAT) in 2000, Whitworth successfully pushed the toy maker to dump its disastrous $3.5 billion acquisition, the computer-game specialist Learning Co., suffering an almost total loss on the move. Mattel doubled within a year and Whitworth received a gold-leaf Barbie Doll from grateful fellow directors when he left the board in 2003.   Whitworth also played a behind-the-scenes role in prevailing on J.C. Penney (JCP) to sells its underperforming Eckerd Drug Store chain in 2004, and on National Semiconductor (NSM) to get out of the digital-semiconductor-processing business and boost margins in its core analog-chip operations in 2004 and 2005.   Relational pushes for large stock buybacks and ample dividend growth, even though such moves may mean a substantial increase in the debt of target companies. According to Whitworth, the mature companies that the firm often invests in are better off with more debt and less equity on their balance sheets. Fat cash troves can lead companies to make bad acquisitions or poor diversification moves in the course of empire-building. Likewise, excess capital can make managers sloppy and slow to react to downturns by cutting costs. Lower share counts serve to springload operating results, often leading to P/E expansion.   One of Relational's biggest investments, Prudential Financial (PRU), has showered shareholders regularly with dividend increases and stock buybacks on Whitworth's advice. Relational has been a shareholder since shortly after Prudential demutualized in late 2001, and has encouraged the company to redeploy its excess capital in a shareholder-friendly manner. "We love the company because they have taken our advice on capital allocation, board structure and executive compensation," says Whitworth. "The company has done a great job of dumping underperforming units to fatten its cash flow and return on equity, and is now in the sweet spot of life- insurance and retirement-industry products."   Prudential's stock has been a triple for Relational.   If all goes well, Relational likes to work its magic and exit a stock after two to three years. But its investment horizon often proves longer. "It takes a lot longer to turn around big companies," Whitworth observes.   Relational doesn't always have a smooth ride in its investments, despite its exhaustive fundamental research. Unexpected accounting and government-reimbursement problems at Apria Healthcare Group (AHG), a California-based home-health-care provider, torched the stock in 1998; it fell 80%. Whitworth became chairman and Batchelder joined the Apria board that year seeking to salvage their investment. In addition, Relational bought more stock on the lows and brought in new management. Finally, four years later, Relational was able to realize a satisfactory profit on its investment.   Whitworth and Relational endured a six-year "slog" (Whitworth's term) when their investment in the Houston-based trash hauler Waste Management (WMI) collapsed, following revelations of dodgy accounting and heavy insider stock sales ahead of bad news in 1999.   Whitworth parachuted into Houston for three months that summer, serving as temporary chairman of the company. "You haven't lived until you've spent an entire summer in the heat and humidity of Houston," he says.   Current management was dumped and a new CEO brought in. In addition, Whitworth deployed 1,200 accountants to vet the books of each of Waste Management's 600 profit centers. A multibillion-dollar charge resulted, but Relational more than recouped its position in WMI in the next five years.   Relational wasn't so lucky with a 1997 investment in Nuevo Energy. A wholesale management overhaul at the company didn't seem to matter, and the firm's estimates of the company's reserves didn't pan out. Nor did oil prices cooperate. Relational dumped the position in 2002, after losing 70%.   Whitworth forged a somewhat improbable career path to Wall Street. He spent his formative years in the northern Nevada town of Winnemucca, "population of around 4,000 and three hours drive from the nearest major hospital," he says. His dad was an independent mining engineer and geologist, which was often shorthand in the West for a dreamer on the verge of a big score that rarely arrived. Whitworth pere was a millionaire for a time in the '50s but gave it back and then some in Ralph's youth on an ill-starred mercury-mine venture.   Ralph was known around town for his blazing-fast 1965 GTO dragster and his ability to fix cars, appliances and anything else mechanical that locals brought him. He became the local superintendent of parks at the tender age of 19 when his predecessor skipped town without telling the city administration how to operate the elaborate watering system for the local public golf course.   He decided to go to college four years later, after concluding he was just as smart as the college kids he hired during summer vacations. Whitworth worked his way through the University of Nevada at Reno by waitering at night at the local Harrah's casino, filling in at the local law library and installing outdoor sprinkler systems in his negligible spare time. Upon graduation he won a spot at Georgetown Law School. "Good grades and law-board scores helped, but what really counted was the fact that the law school hadn't admitted anybody from Nevada in years," he recalls. He also got a hand from Paul Laxalt, at the time Nevada's arch-conservative senator, for whom he interned and later became a key legislative aide.   Whitworth's impeccable conservative credentials have made him more palatable in corporate boardrooms over the years. In addition to his Laxalt connections, he worked in a senior position on Ronald Reagan's 1984 reelection campaign. "He's well-informed and collegial in the board room," recalls a fellow director who served with Whitworth during the dark days at Waste Management. "He has a strong ethical streak in doing what's right for the shareholder."   This prickly sense of right and wrong sometimes raises the hackles of target companies. After all, Whitworth loves a quote from Adam Smith's Wealth of Nations that puts the blame where it often is due: "The trade of a joint stock company is always managed by a court of directors . . . . It cannot well be expected that they would watch over it with the same anxious vigilance with which the partners in a private copartnery frequently watch over their own . . . .Negligence and profusion [waste], therefore, must always prevail, more or less, in the management of the affairs of such a company."   He also lives by it. Whitworth saw fit to dump the CEO who had saved Relational's bacon in Apria after learning the executive quietly had hired his own wife for a six-figure marketing post at the company.   Relational's campaign at Home Depot illustrates Whitworth's methodology well. There has been no show-boating. His December letter to Nardelli, in which he expressed dissatisfaction with the strategic direction of the company and put it on notice he might launch a proxy fight to garner a seat on the board, was made public by the company and not Relational. Nor did he publicly gloat or make impolitic remarks when Nardelli resigned less than four weeks later.   Whitworth had sized up Nardelli as a lethal mix of arrogance, greed and obtuseness, qualities on display at Home Depot's annual meeting in 2006, when Nardelli not only ordered board members not to attend, but limited shareholder questions and comments to just one minute, at which point microphones were turned off. Nardelli's pay package was a primary bone of contention.   After his fall, Nardelli complained that he had doubled Home Depot's earnings during his six-year reign. But as Whitworth explained to Nardelli's successor, Frank Blake, and two Home Depot directors in a private meeting in Los Angeles four weeks ago, the earnings skein didn't tell the entire story. In that six-year period, Home Depot's stock had barely risen while shares of feisty rival Lowe's (LOW) had nearly tripled.   For one thing, Nardelli had resorted to superficial fixes to improve the gross margins of Home Depot's 2,000-store retail operation, which proved damaging once the five-year boom in housing and home improvement ended. He replaced a lot of full-time former plumbers and handymen on the sales floor with part-timers who lacked the ability to assist the do-it-yourself crowd the chain long had catered to. The stores grew dingy compared with the roomier, better-lit Lowe's outlets. By 2006, same-store sales at Home Depot had begun to slip, prompting Nardelli to stop reporting comparative-store sales.   Second, Whitworth took exception to Nardelli's $8 billion diversification into the wholesale-supply business. Not only did the move distract management from the bread-and-butter retail business, but the wholesale-supply business had low margins that diluted Home Depot's overall return on investment. Retail enjoyed a return on investment of 22%. But according to supply-industry data on 23 companies that Relational showed the Home Depot bigwigs, wholesalers averaged returns on investment of just 11.2% over 20 years. Moreover, Whitworth noted that in 2005, Home Depot's supply business earned an actual return on invested capital of just 7.9%, rather than the 13% the company claimed.   All this explains the poor performance of Home Depot's stock despite the increase in earnings. Investors, seeing declining returns, merely accorded the stock a lower price-earnings multiple. Since Nardelli's pay package depended mostly on earnings growth and not stock-price performance, however, that is what he delivered.   (MORE TO FOLLOW) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 00:06 ET (05:06 GMT)  Copyright (c) 2007 Dow Jones & Company, Inc.

Headline: Suzuki, Toyota, Honda To Bolster India Dealerships - Nikkei
Story: NEW DELHI (Nikkei)--Japanese automakers plan to expand their sales channels in India in response to an intensifying turf battle among themselves as well as with Western and South Korean competitors in the market, which is growing by 20% a year, The Nikkei reported in its Sunday edition.   Suzuki Motor Corp. (7269) aims to increase the number of local dealerships by 50% to 600 by the end of 2010. The company, which started automobile production and sales in India in 1983 ahead of its domestic rivals, is now the largest player in the market, commanding a 50% share.  It already has an extensive network of 209 local sales firms operating 405 dealerships.   The company intends to set up more showrooms and maintenance depots in regional cities with high growth potential.   Toyota Motor Corp. (7203), which plans to double the number of models on sale in India to eight, will triple the size of its local dealership network to 200 units by 2010, from 63 now. Japan's largest carmaker plans to boost its share of the Indian market to 10% that year, from the current 4%.   Honda Motor Co. (7267), which specializes in sales of luxury vehicles to wealthy customers, will increase the number of dealers to 80 in fiscal 2008 and to more than 100 by fiscal 2010, from 53 at present.   India's automobile market is expected to grow to 2 million units in 2010, up 50%, in line with rising income levels.     (END) Dow Jones Newswires  February 17, 2007 11:48 ET (16:48 GMT)
